story:
The Haiku Project

Anne finding herself
Driving through America
Poetry in motion

After spending the past 2 years on the West "Left" Coast working as a traveling, contract Physical Therapist, I am headed back to the East Coast. My time working in and exploring new places across the United States has been enriching and inspiring. I know I will never lose my love of travel or my fascination with the variety the US holds, the wonders of our states, and the unique cultural differences that are present and deeply rooted among the regions of the America

When my current position in Sacramento, CA ends at the end of January, I will make the journey east by road. As a birthday present to myself, for the last year of my twenties, I will be undertaking a creative endeavor - The Haiku Project, along the way. 

To document my travels back to New York I will be writing a Haiku each day on the back of a postcard from a place I've stopped at that day. Haiku is a form of poetry which, traditionally, uses a season word and a "cut" to compare and contrast two images, events, or situations within the poem. While I will be expanding the tradition into more modern forms of haiku and not adhering strictly to the traditional structure, I believe that using the haiku form of poetry will be ideal for creating the sense of time, place, and movement that I will be creating with my work. I am looking forward to exploring the different feelings that can be formed within the structure of a haiku - with just a few words I will capture a moment in time.

Writing the haiku on a postcard will be a way for me to bond my feelings onto an image of the physical place I am in (or a representation of that place). Selecting the postcard itself will be part of the artistic process - the juxtaposition of the postcard and the poetry will allow for new connections or conflicts of place and feeling. 

My trip will be a discovery not only of new locations along the way, but also my artistic side. When complete, I will compile the haiku postcards into a book - both a travel journal for myself and a piece of art for others. 

As I pursue The Haiku Project with excitement, my only concern has been a financial one. My student loan bills will be due and I will also incur travel costs. I have realized that taking my project onto IndieGoGo is a way to ask for financial support and will also enable me to engage people in The Haiku Project, expanding it in a new way.

My favorite thank you gift for donors is the personalized haiku sent to you on a postcard from somewhere along my journey. I have decided to make this available for a donation of any size - a contribution of any size will help me and I'd like to thank you for being a part of this adventure. If you can't donate at this time, you can still help out by sharing this project with your friends or giving me recommendations for great things to see along the way. 

Traveling across the country will be a time for reflection and appreciation of the many places and people who have brought me to where I am today and I hope that you'll consider supporting The Haiku Project. I can't wait to see what funny, moving, crazy, offbeat inspiration finds me out on the road!

story:
My name is Mark Colman. I am a photographic artist. A self-employed photographer since 1982, I make 100% of my living from my art.

This project will allow me to buy a RAID and SSD (hard drives) for stable archival storage of my images.

Due to the recent unexpected death of my main camera and a recent external hard drive failure, I am asking for your support.

I live to create art and this is so important to further my creative work. I would greatly appreciate your support. My "perk" prints are hugely discounted over my standard rates!

If the project doesn't fully fund, the plan is to use the funds toward securing at least an SSD, and raising the balance required another way.

Please know that your contribution makes a real difference in my life and helps me to continue creating. Deeply appreciated.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools, if you're inspired to help spread the word!

story:
"Yet I wish my will is strong and what I believe will lead me far"


This Project!

  • Naked Winger is a multimedia installation (visual, sound, and heart beat sensor to control additional visuals). It describes the process of fighting against stress and illusions when a human steps on a huge mission or belief, or carries a sudden loss or tragedy. This piece states the importance of walking the line of pressure instead of escaping. The heart beat sensor effects each individual emotional condition and shows the stress level visually in real time with possible affection related to the artist manifesto video. With the “wings”, one can surely fly high, but also may fall heavily; with the naked arms, one will feel the power of a pair of strong grips and its unbreakable belief and tranquility. This piece encourages those who have the will to tear apart excuses, finish the mission, and continue the belief or carrying on the loss. 



Artist!

  • Lane Shi

Electronic compose, sound designer and performer. Originally from China, Currently living in Boston, USA. Naked Winger is her first multimedia art installation. She drives to combine technology with any kinds of art forms and pursue values in humanity.



Continuing!

I have made it so far to just start my first stop-Boston. And I am one step closer now because I reach out to you. Your support will be so much appreciated by the people along this project who need this experience, which includes you. The fund will be going to:

  • Borrowing Gears: projectors, projector screens, sound systems.
  • Getting Accessories: projector cables, speaker cables, power strips, and extension chords.
  • Constructing Materials: woods, cars, staple gun, staples, screws,nails, drills, fabrics for constructing the gallery into a black box.
  • Rent fee for the Gallery throughout different cities and countries.
  • Travel expense throughout the whole journey.


The Impact!

  • This project drives to pass on the encouragement to those who need to take the pressure in order to finish missions or carry on their losses. I want as many as you can experience the installation, and zooms in yourselves, continuing believing in who you are, continuing the unknown pressure that were there or will be there in your life.


Challenges!

  • Through the process of putting everything together includes borrow gears, asking for help to construct, searching for gallery who is interested in starting my first installation, I met tremendous challenges and countless rejects from people or institutions due to many reasons including that I am a young artist and just start my first art installation. However, I still receive a lot of helps from many individuals, and I will not give up this project and cannot wait to have it exhibit elsewhere besides Boston. I hope that those who have the interest in hosting the exhibition in their cities will contact me and continue this project with me together.


Other Ways You Can Help!

It is understandable if you cannot donate. There are so many ways to help!

  • Getting the word out about this installation. SHARE IT with everyone! https://www.facebook.com/Laneshiotayonii?fref=ts
  • Come out to the installation when it reaches to your cities or countries!
  • Hosting this exhibition in the galleries you can contact with.
  • Volunteer to help me with the next exhibition stop.
  • Be strong and believe who you are.


Special Thanks:
Miguel Ozuna                  Anda Volley              Daniel Galindo                     Harley Cullen Erik Jackson                    Marvin Lorenzo Wang       Eric Alper                 Dara Pannebaker Steve MacLean              Andrew Wise

AND THOSE WHO HELP IN ANY WAYS!

story:
Summary

As the longest-running and most influential integrated media arts festival in Canada Images is dedicated to moving-image art in all its forms. The Images Festival is a venue for moving image art that provides artists with a supportive and professional forum in which to present their work and to connect with each other, with curators and programmers, as well as with audiences that expect and appreciate the unusual, the surprising, and the inventive.

Images was created in response to issues of accessibility, breaking down barriers created by industry conventions. From the beginning, the organization championed alternatives to commercial media, and fought to open up critical dialogue about power, representation and censorship. 

2016 Images Festival April 14-23 full catalogue:

https://issuu.com/imagesfestival2016/docs/if2016_catalogue_fa_low_res/3?e=2

Your support 

Your donation will help us create a progressive, inclusive and engaging international platform for moving image culture, keep programming accessible, and support emerging and cutting-edge perspectives.

For the 29th annual festival more than %70 of our programming free or pwyc, and discounted for students, seniors and underemployed. 

Supporting Images will grant you access to festival events, tickets to special live events, as well as other great incentives with partnering organizations. 

Tax receipts may be issued for a portion of your donation. Please ask for details. Our charitable registration number is #12741 8762 RR0001.

Festival Passes and Vouchers *Some restrictions apply.

Festival Pass and vouchers offer free general admission to festival screenings, but are not valid for all events, such as Opening, Live, and Closing. Vouchers redeemable in-person at the Advance Box Office. While your admission with festival pass and voucher is FREE, it doesn’t guarantee you a seat. We recommend arriving at least 30 minutes before the scheduled start time.

Pick up at the Advance Box Office during the festival.
Email: membership@imagesfestival.com

The Impact

"Being part of the Images festival was an honour I will never forget. As an emerging artist, I felt that the inclusion of my work in the festival signified a welcoming into the community, it helped to elevate the way my work is viewed...the festival propelled my career forward."

— Caitlin Durlak, Best Student Video and Home Brew Award (2015)

"Finding a niche for my experimental animations has often been difficult and I was so happy to have been invited to screen at a festival for which I have great respect and admiration. My thanks to everyone involved with the festival and those who support its existence and mission."

— Calvin Frederick, Best Student Film Award (2015)

"The Images Festival has empowered me and many others to connect and share our work. It has proved to be a valuable place where different artists can come together under one roof to share new and exciting visions for the future.”

— Paul Nguyen, Tom Berner Award (2015)

"Experimental media practices are so wonderfully diverse, changeable and unpredictable, that it’s not always easy to know what the criteria for success or failure are at any given time. Festivals help – particularly, reliably well-run festivals like Images."

— Gary Kibbins, Less is More Award (2015)

Ways You Can Help

Please help us by sharing our campaign and joining us at the festival April 14-23, 2016.

CREDITS FOR VIDEO 

Clips from: Tomorrow is Always Too Long by Phil Collins, From Gulf to Gulf by CAMP Collective, Akumassa (installation view) by Jorge Lozano, fog vortex (installation view) by Christina Battle, Casey Wei (artist talk), Phantom Limbs (installation view) piece by Luis Jacob, Chris Curreri, Samuel Beckett, Witness: Palestine (performance view) by Barbara Hammer, Spectres of the Future (installation view) by Victoria Delle Donne, James Rollo, Franco Arcieri and Sook Jung, 2004 Images Festival Trailer, 8 (installation view) by Bjorn Kammerer, The ADS Epidemic by John Greyson, Althea Thauberger (Artist Q & A), Wendy (live reading) by Walter Scott, Colour Opponent Process by Aura Satz, How Many Performance Artists Does it Take to Change a Light Bulb (performance view) by Jess Dobkin, 2015 Festival Trailer by Oliver Husain, Beneath Your Skin of Deep Hollow by Malena Szlam. Music: "Oh December My Love" by Justin Small. Video by Dylan Reibling.

CREDITS FOR VIDEO 

Clips from: Tomorrow is Always Too Long by Phil Collins, From Gulf to Gulf by CAMP Collective, Akumassa (installation view) by Jorge Lozano, fog vortex (installation view) by Christina Battle, Casey Wei (artist talk), Phantom Limbs (installation view) piece by Luis Jacob, Chris Curreri, Samuel Beckett, Witness: Palestine (performance view) by Barbara Hammer, Spectres of the Future (installation view) by Victoria Delle Donne, James Rollo, Franco Arcieri and Sook Jung, 2004 Images Festival Trailer, 8 (installation view) by Bjorn Kammerer, The ADS Epidemic by John Greyson, Althea Thauberger (Artist Q & A), Wendy (live reading) by Walter Scott, Colour Opponent Process by Aura Satz, How Many Performance Artists Does it Take to Change a Light Bulb (performance view) by Jess Dobkin, 2015 Festival Trailer by Oliver Husain, Beneath Your Skin of Deep Hollow by Malena Szlam. Music: "Oh December My Love" by Justin Small. Video by Dylan Reibling.

story:
L'associazione equinozio nasce nel 2006 e produce e promuove eventi artistici in collaborazione con Istituzioni, teatri e luoghi di cultura organizzata e spontanea, creando circuiti culturali


EAT ART è una mostra che fa parte di un progetto realizzato con tre associazioni in Europa e co-finanziato da Creative Europe Culture. I nostri partner sono: 
Ostrale di Dresda, (una galleria d'arte contemporanea alternativa).
Swiat Nadziei di Breslavia (una associazione che si promuove gli artisti diversamente abili).
Netwerk  di Aalst (una centro multidisciplinare per l'arte contemporanea).


L'associazione ha creato questo circuito di artisti e ha ottenuto gli spazi per la mostra: la palazzina Seicentro in via Savona 99 e le sale espositive della Biblioteca Valvassori Peroni (numero 56). 


Con il tuo contributo vorremmo arricchire la mostra di eventi musicali, performance e workshop con artisti italiani a stranieri. In questo modo le tre settimane dell'esposizione di Eat Art si riempiranno  di appuntamenti da non perdere .
Il contributo che chiediamo verrà quindi utilizzato per promuovere e realizzare:
  • Quattro concerti di musica classica: Concerto del Centro musicale Suzuky, Trio Chitarra Mandolino e voce, Performance del Coro città di Milano, Concerto di chitarra classica
  • Due performance dedicate al tema della mostra, All You Can It e Slow Atoms
  • Un Work Shop di food sensoriality experience.
  • Un incontro dedicato alla naturopatia dal titolo "alimentarsi con arte"
  • Uno spettacolo di Teatro danza dedicato al valore simbolico del cibo nella fiaba e nel mito.

Aiutaci, se non potete contribuire a diffondere l'iniziativa!


Equinozio Association was founded in 2006, it produces and promotes art events in collaboration with Institution, theaters and cultural venues organized and spontaneous, creating cultural circuits.

 EAT ART is an exhibition that is part of a project with three European associations and co-funded by the Creative Europe Culture. 

Our partners are: Ostrale from Dresden, (a contemporary art gallery alternative). Swiat Nadziei from Wroclaw (an association that promotes artists with disabilities). Netwerk from Aalst (a multidisciplinary center for contemporary art). Equinozio has created this circuit of artists and has obtained two important venues for exhibition: the building Sei Centro, located in Via Savona 99  and exhibition halls of the Library Valvassori Peroni (via Valvassori Peroni 56). 

Now we ask your contribution to enrich the exhibition of musical events, performances and workshops with Italian and foreigners artists .

 In this way the three-week EAT ART exhibition  will be filled with unmissable events and to achieve them you come in! 

The contribution we ask will then be used to promote and realize:

 • Four classical music concerts: Concert of the Music Center Suzuki, Mandolin and Guitar Trio voice, Performance Choir city of Milan, concert classical guitar

 • Two performances on the theme of the exhibition, All You Can It Slow and Atoms

 • A Work Shop of food sensoriality experience. 

• A meeting dedicated to naturopathy entitled "feed with art"

 • A show of dance theater dedicated to the symbolic value of food in the fairy tale and myth. 

Help us, if you can not, you can help spread the initiative!

story:
Help fund 'So What Do You Do?' 
+
Book a coach ticket to the exhibition.

 

I need your help and I would love for you to join me for the opening of 'So What Do You Do?' a solo exhibition at Dsyfunction Gallery outside of Glasgow in Strahaven. 

I am really excited (and nervous) to present an all new series of sculptures, video and print works for this exhibition. It is formed around subjects that I feel passionate about and I look forward to sharing it with you all.

I have arranged a coach for up to 24 people to make it easier for people to travel to the opening. On this page you can book a return coach ticket or order another perk to help support and fund the exhibition's production. Costs will help cover ceramic and bronze productions, digital prints, tool hire and production costs, electrical equipment and coach hire.

You can also donate any amount by clicking the pink 'Back it' button.

A big thank you to all that help support this show and my work.

 

Perk 1 - Coach ticket, Good karma + A5 2-colour risograph £10

Book a return coach ticket from The Art School, Glasgow to Dsyfunction Gallery in Strathaven on the opening evening Friday 10th March.  Pick up at 7pm (The Art School) - return journey at 9pm from the Gallery (journey is roughly 40mins). You will also receive an A5 2-colour risograph print edition of 25. Best of all you will receive a big thank you and good karma for supporting me and what I do.

 

Perk 2 - A4  2-colour risograph print + Good karma £10

You will receive a signed A4 2-colour risograph print edition of 20. You will receive a follow up email to choose which print you like. Best of all you will receive a big thank you and good karma for supporting me and what I do.  

 

Perk 3 -  Engraved necklace + Good karma £20

You will receive an editioned 'Graft Til You Die' black engraved acrylic necklace . Best of all you will receive a big thank you and good karma for supporting me and what I do.

 

Perk 4 - Sterling silver signet ring + Good karma £90

You will receive a very limited edition 'Graft Til You Die' sterling silver signet ring, made to size. Best of all you will receive a big thank you and good karma for supporting me and what I do.

 

A short artist bio

I am an artist, designer and curator based in Glasgow. Founder of Beta-Beta and co-founder of Common Ground arts organisations and previous committee member at The Telfer Gallery. Selected exhibitions include: Mute (Lisbon), Galerie Visualise (Marseille), Acca (Turin), Fjuk Arts Centre (Husavik), Primary, Pipe Factory, Generator Projects, The Number Shop and Xero, Kline & Koma.

 

Big thank you to all that donate, contribute and attend the exhibition. As Brian Eno says you are all 'Sceniuses', without you arts and culture cannot flourish.

 

Please share the campaign and bring a friend along.

story:
中文產品說明


When was the last time you looked up at the moon?

Divine and serene, the moon is a resting place for our heart. 

After a long day, we sometimes want to take a glimpse at the moon for a sense of relief, only to find skyscrapers in the city...

But now, you can bring the moon along with you.

Inspired by the moon, the artwork ─ Luna, hopes to bring more delight and content into your life. Indulge yourself into the moonlight. Let Luna illuminate your space, and your mind.


It's the design decor that turns your space into a magical world. It's the lamp that lightens up your favorite reading corner. You decide what Luna is, and how you want to make your life prettier with it.

When Luna joins a space...


When Luna meets people...




Luna is mainly made of glass fiber and non-toxic latex. Its luminosity ranges from LUX1 to LUX5.

If you want to hang Luna on the ceiling, simply install a hook on the ceiling, use a durable string (nylon string is recommended here - it's strong and transparent), pass the cord through the ring on top of Luna and hang it on the hook. 

7 Sizes of Luna


Every Luna comes with a cord, and a device to adjust luminosity. Luna M (and smaller) uses E27/28W/110V Halogen bulbs; Luna L (and bigger) uses E27/42W/110V Halogen bulbs.

Luna XXS is an exception: the unique mini lantern is equipped with an LED bulb and a battery instead of a Halogen bulb and a cord. The luminosity is not adjustable, and it's not suitable for hanging. 



Aiming to bring rich imagination to people about their spaces ─ living rooms, studios, yards and so on, we want to overcome the limits of conventional decoration. The moon has been a divine and enchanting symbol in human history, and it brings you mystery, delight, relief and romance. Luna unveils the potential of a space.

We human beings often think that it is ourselves who create and influence our own environment. In fact, interaction exists between humans and their surroundings ─ our environment affects our mind and emotions as well. Decorate your own world with Luna ─ into any style you want. It's not only an art of decorating, but an art of living. 

By creating a crowdfunding project, we hope to raise funds for the production of Luna, and share the amazing artwork with the world.


We hand-crafted all of our products. Each and every Luna is handmade and one-of-a-kind.

We have devoted lots of effort designing the exterior of Luna, and figured out the most suitable materials to use. Now Luna is ready for production. The production process of Luna is shown below:

In order to present you an unique and exquisite artwork, throughout the production, we have very rigorous quality control. We insist every single detail of our product to be perfect. 


The first and second product shipment were expected in March and May 2016, as indicated in the campaign. But in one of our updates we've announced that, after putting much effort, we'll start shipping product batches successively since Dec 2015!


OVER 750% RAISED!  STRETCH GOAL UNLOCKED, AMAZING GIFT TO BE RECEIVED!

As promised, we're giving you the lovely and amazing gifts ─ exquisite accessories that match perfectly with Luna! 

Bring your dreams to the moon ─ Meet the astronaut, the spacecraft and the rocket!


Dear backers, Thank you for joining the ride with us. Amazed by this overwhelming love and support, we have worked even harder to return the favor. So here's the exciting news: As you knew, Luna's product shipment was expected in March and May, 2016. But now, we will start shipping product batches successively since DECEMBER 2015! Hooray! 



The ultimate exploration and pursuit of interior design objects is always enjoyable. Acorn Studio wants to redefine the relationships between humans and spaces, and continue to bring breakthroughs in the industry.

We have always been hoping to create works that bring people pleasure, satisfaction and amazement. We choose to express and live out our values by art. Luna seems to be a simple artwork, but it fully contains the spirit of Acorn Studio. We hope that you get more happiness and wonders when Luna joins your life. :)

More amazing moments with Luna...



1. Q: What are the features of Luna ? 

     A: It's water resistant, heat resistant and crashworthy.

2. Q: When will I receive my order?

     A: The first and second product shipment were expected in March and May 2016, as indicated in the campaign. But in one of our updates we've announced that, after putting much effort, we'll start shipping product batches successively since Dec 2015!

     (We handcraft each and every Luna, and make sure all of them are perfect. Since so many people have ordered, it takes some time for product production. )

3. Q: Is Luna topographically accurate?

     A: Luna is an artwork inspired by the moon, and it doesn't aim at being topographically accurate. It has its own artistic interpretation.

4. Q: What should I do if I’ve bought one Luna and want to buy one more?

     A: Please simply contribute to one more perk. :)

5. Q: Do I get a discount on the price/shipping fee if I buy more than one Luna?

     A: On the prices: The current prices of Luna are already discounted ones!

          On the shipping fee: Two Luna doubles the volumetric weight, so the shipping companies would charge twice. (I.e. no discount will be provided by them)

6. Q: What color is the light of Luna?

     A: It's close to a warm, light yellow kind of light.

7. Q: What type of plug and voltage is it for Luna?

     A: It's two-prong plug and 110V. Since the plug and voltage condition vary in         different countries, please prepare your own plug adapter and converter if needed.

8. Q: How long is the cord of Luna?

     A: It's roughly 13.12 feet with the luminosity adjusting device.

9. Q: Why is the shipping fee expensive?

     A: Though Luna is basically crashworthy and we made careful packaging, it is still considered fragile by courier companies. So it'll be charged a higher shipping fee.

10. Q: Can we change the light bulb inside Luna?

     A: Yes. You can remove the lid and change the light bulb. But notice: we don’t recommend changing light bulbs. Due to safety concerns, we made the lid pretty sturdy.So if not necessary, don't change the light bulb.

11. Q: Can I wash Luna?

     A: You can wash Luna by brushing slightly with water.

12. Q: Is there a warranty on Luna?

    A: Yes, we provide an one-year warranty. Under normal usage, if malfunction or damage occurs, you can send Luna back to us to get it repaired. 

13. Q: Which kind of battery is used inside Luna XXS (3.2 inch Luna)?

     A: Mercury batteries (LR41).

14. Q: Will Luna be damaged in the shipment process?

     A: We’ve used careful packaging as a way of protection, so you don’t have to worry about it.

Disclaimer required in Paypal policies: "Delivery of rewards/perks is subject to best efforts and not guaranteed."

Disclaimer required in Paypal policies: "Delivery of rewards/perks is subject to best efforts and not guaranteed."

story:
Fund the underfunded!

Hi, I am Amy "Zing" Gray.  I am a professional puppeteer and improvisational comedian in Portland, OR.  I have worked at my craft for over 20 years and have toured to schools across the West with Tears of Joy Theatre, and performed  in over a thousand shows with ComedySportz.  I have designed puppets, masks, props, soundtracks, and sets.  I have directed several shows and created many of my own.  I have performed in tiny countryside libraries and huge modern arts centers.  I have brought my worlds together in a very popular "Puppets Vs. People" improv show.

Something remarkable happened to me this month.  I had an exciting  opportunity, but that opportunity fell through.  And in the meantime, I had an adventure which showed me how much support I really have in my life as an artist.

Your Money

I have already exceeded my goal.
All money will be distributed throughout these categories.  I intend to use a special account to keep track of all the monies.

Perks! oh we've got Perks!
I am drawing on my artistic skills to provide you with thank-you perks.
Examples of the puppets can be found in the gallery.

Here is my pastels website:       www.amyzingarts.com

Why Amy?

I am overwhelmed by the flow of support coming out of both the puppet and Improv communities in Portland.  Thank you all.


Where's it going?

The funds raised will be invested in several aspects of my art.  I would like to purchase some tools for my workbench.  I would like to get more prints of my work made, and enter into more art fairs. And I would like to get a car share membership, to help me perform my shows around town.

In fact, I am open to suggestions, but treating your gifts ethically is my main concern and I will keep you posted about how all the money is spent.

On the other hand, If a miracle presents itself, I will say YES to it.  I will not give up entirely or easily.  This is too important.


    BROKE?  That's Okay!
    If you can't make a $$ contribution, you can still help me out, by sharing and spreading my campaign. 
    Use the share tools on this page. 
    You can send me cheerful messages, I really appreciate them.

my workbench.  I would like to get more prints of my work made, and enter
 into more art fairs. And I would like to get a car share membership, to
 help me perform my shows around town. 
In fact, I am open to 
suggestions, but treating your gifts ethically is my main 
concern and I will keep you posted about how all the money is spent.
On the other hand, If a miracle presents itself, I will say YES to it.  I will not give up entirely or easily.  This is too important.

   BROKE?  That's Okay!
 If you can't make a $$ contribution, you can still help me out, by sharing and spreading my campaign.  Use the share tools on this page.  You can send me cheerful messages, I really appreciate them.

story:
"Women of the World"

Hi! I am a mom of two and a mom-entrepreneur! I work in interior design for a living but drawing is my passion. I have decided to do something ONLY out of passion! My campaign is to help me launch my own adult colouring book. I want this for many reasons, but most of all:

  • I want my boys to see their mom go after a dream and accomplish what she sets out to do! My oldest has been telling me for a long time that I should sell my drawings, so I am following his expert advice! ;)
  • I want to do something that fuels my passions and my creativity. Something that inspires others too!

By helping me in my campaign, you will be helping me accomplish a dream, and you will participate in the publishing of a beautiful colouring book!

What I Need & What You Get

The funds I need will simply pay for self-publication by iUniverse, a company that provides people like me with great service and help with their book. The goal is to get my book published and sale it online through Amazon and Indigo|Chapter's. After that, I will use the printed copy to go look for a publisher and/or libraries that will put my book on their shelves.

If you participate in my funding, check out the perks you could get!

If ever I don't get all the funding I need, I will use the money to pursue my dream and get as many copies printed as the money allows. I will then use those to get a publisher and librairies to get onboard.

After this book, I will continue to draw for other books of the same type: "Motherhood around the world", "Powerful women around the world", etc...

My goal is to touch people, make women aware of what it is to be a woman everywhere in the world. 

Thank you for helping a mom make her kids (and herself) proud! Share the word, it's easy!

story:
What is The Art Cart?

The Art Cart  is a rolling gallery that brings the work of contemporary artists to various communities in Charleston, and the larger South Carolina Community. It's primary goals are to: 


1 - support contemporary artists in Charleston, SC by providing an alternative exhibition space.

2 - expand the artist and community experience of contemporary art by offering exhibitions of invited artists from around the country.

3 - introduce various communities to new artwork by bringing the artwork to them. Communities will include the downtown area, public parks/gathering places, and traditionally non-art viewing neighborhoods.

4 - Provide a rolling workshop where exhibiting/participating artists can bring art-making projects to the local community including seniors, families, and students.


The Art Cart is an artist-led project, founded by Jonell Jaime Pulliam.  Pulliam is an artist and educator with over 13 years of experience working in museums, colleges, and community based organizations in New York City and  Charleston, SC. 


Art Cart: The Impact

The Art Cart will have a direct impact on a number of members of the community.


Artists: Contemporary artists have limited exhibition opportunities in the Charleston area. This project will provide artists with an alternative venue led by artists to show their work. The mobile element of the project will allow the work to be seen by a diverse audience, while providing artists a valuable opportunity to build their resume.


Artists from the region will also be able to expand their relationship with practices in contemporary art by seeing the work of invited artists from around the Country.


Families/Children: The art cart will not only work as an exhibition space, but a portable workshop that will bring complementary arts programming to the community. Families who do not to access museum and galleries as a result of distance, cost, or comfort will still be able to explore the arts and support the creativity of their children through roadside exhibitions and workshops right in the neighborhood.


Workshops provide a great opportunity for the collaboration of artists across disciplines. Musicians, vocalists, writers, and visual artists will be invited to lead workshops in conjunction with exhibitions.


What We Need

Artists are already committed to the project! We need a permanent Art Cart!

$4000 will go towards the purchasing of a used bread truck.
$1000 covers the cost of repairs.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? Spread the word and encourage friends, family, and anyone else you know to support the project!

story:
WHO AM I? WHY HELP ME?

Hi! I'm Miss Catherine! I am an industrial designer, steezy costume curator, props extraordinaire, 4 time burner and active member in the San Diego Burning Man community and lover of pizza.  I am passionate about making awesome, entertaining, worthwhile and beautiful things that enhance people's lives in a fun way. Whether it be props for Desert Hearts Festival, giant octopus tentacles for a pirate themed Lovelife boat party, or simply smaller creations for gifts or functional design, I put all of my creativity and energy into each project. I think most people would agree I usually go WAY over the top with my ideas, because each project means so so so much to me. 

This project is especially  important to me because although it was originally graciously funded and sponsored by my former camp Shangri-Lawless, I have now repaid their investment and taken full ownership of it. This is the first large project that I have worked on in a long time that is 100% MINE. I have put so much into this project already and while it was a functional success in 2015, it lacked the detail and sparkle factor that I believe this project deserves. I am determined to put everything I have into bringing the horse back to the playa next month at her full potential.

By helping fund this project you are not only helping a Rocking Horse get to the playa, but you are supporting both my dream to create wonderful things and my passion for good design, sparkle, and a rockin good time. It means the world to me, thank you so much!

HISTORY

In 2014 my good friend and Burning Man campmate, Moki, had the idea of acquiring some rocking horses to tie up outside of our camp Shangri-Lawless as an ode to the western half of our namesake. I instantly loved the idea and although we were not able to make it happen that year, in 2015 I made it my mission to see the project through. 

Originally I planned on collecting rocking horses to bring, but quickly discovered that rocking horses are not only expensive, but they are almost never adult sized or big enough to be enjoyed by a large group of people... I had to design my own.

 With the financial backing from my theme camp I was able to achieve my goal and bring my newborn 6 foot tall, 6 foot long rocking horse to the 9:30 and B corner of Black Rock City.

She was a beautiful horse, but she, like many of us at our first burn, was lacking steezy style, and the kind of finery that could help her reach her full potential. She was a basic horse with no  lights, no mane or tail, no reins or stirrups and some subpar lasercut eyes.

Regardless, she brought the cowboy out in thousands of people. Visitors to our camp were brought back to their childhood as they climbed aboard this magical stallion. It is hard to tell before experiencing for yourself, but she is super fun to ride. Maybe it is the danger of being so high off the ground, her unique design that allows for creative riding styles including standing, sitting, wheelies, and more. She is designed in a way that makes it very difficult to take it too far, even if it feel like you might be close to the edge.

CONSTRUCTION

 

The horse was made by using a CNC to precisely cut the high quality baltic birch wood pieces. The pieces were then glued and bracketed together to form the working horse. Using this process made the horse stronger and more durable as well as less likely to warp under the high temperatures of the Black Rock Desert. The horse is made up of 2 double reinforced sides with support pieces down the center that hold the sides at a slight inward angle. She is completed by a 2 inch thick acrylic block with an ornate heart laser etched into it that is visible from the front of the horse.

 

BURNING MAN 2016 VISION: A REAL SPARKLE PONY

With the exception of some minor repairs and reinforcements, the structure is still in great shape thanks to a really strong original design. Now it’s time for to make this pony really sparkle and shine for all of Black Rock City to enjoy. Here are the additions that I hope to make this year:

  • Apply a laser cut holographic film to her exterior she will sparkle with the sparkliest of sparkle ponies during the daytime.
  • Add a fiberoptic mane and tail that will compliment rainbow led light that will light up her laser etched acrylic heart at night.
  • Add above-standard pony accessories like stirrups and reins.
  • Allow for pony-mobility to other camps and nearby areas of Black Rock City

 

 

FUNDING

I have been working very hard to develop an accurate list of the dreams I have for her second journey to Black Rock City next month and also special gifts that I can offer as a thank you to contributors. Outside of what I am asking for, I have personally invested over $300 to this project. I am confident that with your help, and a lot of hard work, I can make this the best rocking horse of all time.

Below is a list of prioritized costs. As I raise money, these are the items your money will go towards, and in this order. This way, even if I do not reach my full goal, she will still make it to the playa with as much steez her funds will allow. I have researched exactly what each part will cost and I am confident that I will be able to complete this project within the requested budget.

  • Transportation to & From Burning Man - $300
  • Fiber Optic Tail & Mane - $200
  • Holographic Vinyl- $60
  • Rainbow LED Lights for the heart- $40
  • Solar powered battery packs - $40
  • Leather Reins- $50
  • Leather Stirrups- $50
  • Rolling platform (to transport Pony to parties at nearby friends camps so more people can enjoy her) - $45
  • Cost for incentive prize materials, laser time and mailing costs - $150
  • Indiegogo Fees (5% if goal is met, 10% if goal is not met) - Indiegogo takes some of this money for helping host this awesome page, I am factoring this in so we do not come up short. If you want to make a direct contribution or have some of the above supplies you could donate instead, please contact Miss Catherine and we can set it up.
  • Miscellaneous - this is for things like glue, screws, zip ties, tape, etc. These little things add up and I need them to make magic happen and repair her throughout the week if needed.- $40

**What I am NOT using the money for** I think it is important to note that all of the funds raised will go directly to costs like supplies, transportation, or Indiegogo fees. I am not paying myself for my time designing, building, tinkering, or any other soft execution costs. The many hours of work I put in to make this project a reality is my gift.

 

REWARDS - JUMP ON IT!!

I am so grateful for any contributions to this project and the best way I could think to properly thank those who donate is with a gift. Although I did account for some of the incentive cost, the majority of what goes into the incentives is a donation of my time and creativity to give something to you as a thank you for supporting me and my project. Please note that not all incentives will be fulfilled before Burning Man, check individual incentive descriptions for more info.

*Every single person who donates $1 or more will have their name engraved on the inside of the horse above/below her heart where all riders can see the love and generosity that went into her creation* (if you do not want your name engraved please let me know when you donate)

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

SHARE SHARE SHARE!! Please tell all of your friends via social media and this project also makes a good conversation topic anytime!!

If you have a non-monetary way you would like to help or are able to donate one of the items listed on the budget please contact me at catherine.worsham@gmail.com

If you would like to donate time in September helping me organize and mail all of the incentives that would also be awesome!

 

A BIG THANK YOU ...

to those who have already been huge supporters and contributed in a variety of ways- this project would not exist without you all <3 Shangri- Lawless, Moki, Pearson Courtney, Julia Kerr, GoBe, Walter Worsham, Ryan Freckle, Leeward Bound, Justine Fritz, Kim Battaglin Ryan White, King John Henry, Angeline May Smile, and Seeya Sia.

 

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR ANY AND ALL SUPPORT!! Be sure to come ride my pony on playa at 9:30 & H- Camp BAEwatch, and beyond!

story:
Can you help us get to $2,000? ~ Any amount helps & we are grateful for your support!


What is That Which Is Most Beautiful? (referred to with affection as "TWIMBY")

You approach a radiant and beautiful circular structure with vibrantly colored walls that glow from within.  At night, the colors fluoresce and resonate under black lights.  A sign above the entrance entices you with the words, â€œTHAT WHICH IS MOST BEAUTIFUL.â€ You enter into the glowing labyrinth filled with wonder and anticipation. What will I find in here? Your â€œwalk in beautyâ€ is inspired by the DinÃ© peopleâ€™s understanding that we create the world around us, and if we walk with beauty in our hearts and minds, the world will be a more beautiful place.

This interactive art installation is designed to allow participants to fully immerse in a beautiful and moving experience of color, music, and inspirational words.  As visitors travel through the labyrinth, they will read beautiful, powerful words of wisdom written upon the walls â€“ pearls which have been shared with us by some of the worldâ€™s respected indigenous leaders, healers and wisdom keepers. Those who are walking within the labyrinth will also hear blessings, songs, chants and drumming from many of these wise people. All of these recordings were given to the Ringing Rocks Foundation to be shared with the people of the world.

â€œDuring my time at Ringing Rocks, I was blessed to spend time with many of the worldâ€™s Wisdom Keepers.  It was an unbelievable privilege to sit with these elders and listen to the powerful words they shared. It is my sincerest wish, that, as people walk through this labyrinth, they feel a bit of the magic one experiences when listening to the deep wisdom of our elders,â€ says Stephen DeNorscia, co-creator of That Which is Most Beautiful. â€œThis is not a religious experience - the wisdom these elders are sharing is nothing new to us. It is wisdom we ALL hold in our hearts. It moves us because it is TRUE. The goal of this project is to allow all who experience it to be moved in a deep, personal, and beautiful way.â€


The Impact

We anticipate that TWIMBY will have numerous positive impacts - many impossible to anticipate and we're excited to find out!


* For visitors to the installation, it will provide a stimulating and joyful sensory environment, as well as having the potential to be a profound psychological and emotional catharsis - a vivid reminder of our spiritual connection with all beings, and a validation of our intrinsic value and uniqueness, as individual members of the human family.


* For the indigenous leaders who have shared with us some of their wisdom and prayers, we honor their wishes that we pass this on to others in our community.


*We'd love to make the labyrinth available to people outside of the Apogaea Festival on other occasions


* For the co-creators who build this project with us, there will be friendships forged, community strengthened, skills learned and practiced in a non-judgemental atmosphere of creative play, repeated cycles of productivity and celebration.. the joy of Getting Big Stuff Done With Friends And Having Fun While Doing It!


Seriously... Art Saves Lives. 


Community + Creativity + Craftsmanship + Play = Happy, Healthy and Empowered People


What We Need & What You Get

Please consider making a contribution via PayPal, if you can, as this allows us to receive funds faster. Otherwise, you can use a credit card.


The estimated cost to complete this project in full is $3,000  Ì¶  a very small price to bring such beauty into the world. Via an art grant provided by Apogaea, we have already raised $1,000. Please help us reach our ultimate goal with your generous contribution. We are sincerely grateful for your assistance.


We've set our current IndieGoGo goal lower than the total amount we need, to ensure that we will be successful in raising essential funds early on. We need to place vital materials orders in March, so that our work can be completed in May. If we can raise raise the $2,000 we need by March 14th, then wow! We'll be on our way without having to run another campaign.


We are also accepting donations and/or loans of materials, to bring our costs down. Please let us know if you have leads on any of the following materials.


Materials Required
~30 Black lights (48" wide, 110 watts)
~400 linear feet of 60" bleached muslin fabric
150 2x4s 8' long
10 sheets of 1/2" plywood
100 Rebar Stakes (36" - 48")

6 gallons of blacklight-reactive paint
1 gallon house paint (dark blue)
Blacklight fabric pens
1,000' nylon rope
~250 yards cotton "herringbone" ribbon for ties
Zip Ties (8" - 12â€, ~200)
Extra Large Paint Brushes/Clean Mops
Wood Screws
Plastic Trash Barrels (6, ~15-30 gallons)

Drills (2-3 cordless)
Circular Saw
Extension Cords (10 - 12, 100â€™ long)
Power Strips (~12)
6â€™ Ladder (2 - 3)
gasoline for generator (~20 gallons)
Carpet (~25â€™ long by 4â€™ wide)
Transportation costs



Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out! Even a $5 contribution from a distant and sympathetic supporter will help bring this beautiful project to fruition. (A stranger is just a friend we haven't met yet...)


Share on via Facebook, Twitter or email!


If you want to participate in one of this Spring's FUN work parties, just request membership in our co-creators' Facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/171811372931110/  We'll keep you posted there.

* For visitors to the installation, it will provide a stimulating and joyful sensory environment, as well as having the potential to be a profound psychological and emotional catharsis - a vivid reminder of our spiritual connection with all beings, and a validation of our intrinsic value and uniqueness, as individual members of the human family.

* For the indigenous leaders who have shared with us some of their wisdom and prayers, we honor their wishes that we pass this on to others in our community.



*We'd love to make the labyrinth available to people outside of the Apogaea Festival on other occasions


* For the co-creators who build this project with us, there will be friendships forged, community strengthened, skills learned and practiced in a non-judgemental atmosphere of creative play, repeated cycles of productivity and celebration.. the joy of Getting Big Stuff Done With Friends And Having Fun While Doing It!


Seriously... Art Saves Lives. 

Community + Creativity + Craftsmanship + Play = Happy, Healthy and Empowered People

What We Need & What You Get
Please consider making a contribution via PayPal, if you can, as this allows us to receive funds faster. Otherwise, you can use a credit card.

The estimated cost to complete this project in
full is $3,000  Ì¶  a very
small price to bring such beauty into the world. Via an art grant provided
by Apogaea, we have already raised $1,000. Please help us reach our ultimate
goal with your generous contribution. We are sincerely grateful for your
assistance.

We've set our current IndieGoGo goal lower than the total amount we need, to ensure that we will be successful in raising essential funds early on. We need to place vital materials orders in March, so that our work can be completed in May. If we can raise raise the $2,000 we need by March 14th, then wow! We'll be on our way without having to run another campaign.

We are also accepting donations and/or loans of materials, to bring our costs down. Please let us know if you have leads on any of the following materials.

Materials Required~30 Black lights (48" wide, 110 watts)~400 linear feet of 60" bleached muslin fabric150 2x4s 8' long10 sheets of 1/2" plywood100 Rebar Stakes (36" - 48")6 gallons of blacklight-reactive paint1 gallon house paint (dark blue)Blacklight fabric pens1,000' nylon rope~250 yards cotton "herringbone" ribbon for tiesZip Ties (8" - 12â€, ~200)
Extra Large Paint Brushes/Clean Mops
Wood Screws
Plastic Trash Barrels (6, ~15-30 gallons)
Drills (2-3 cordless)Circular SawExtension Cords (10 - 12, 100â€™ long)Power Strips (~12)6â€™ Ladder (2 - 3)gasoline for generator (~20 gallons)Carpet (~25â€™ long by 4â€™ wide)
Transportation costs

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out! Even a $5 contribution from a distant and sympathetic supporter will help bring this beautiful project to fruition. (A stranger is just a friend we haven't met yet...)

Share on via Facebook, Twitter or email!

If you want to participate in one of this Spring's FUN work parties, just request membership in our co-creators' Facebook group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/171811372931110/  We'll keep you posted there.

story:
Hi there, we are Ali and Christian! Nice to meet you :) We are two designers who have been together for almost(!) two years now. We are taking the trip of our dreams very soon, and we are calling upon the powers of the internet and friendship to help us!




We met in the glorious spring of 2012. Well, we met on the internet way before that, but our first real hug was in the spring of 2012. It was like this—Christian was traveling around North America, and was in Toronto at the time. Ali offered him a place to stay in Calgary, just to hang out as friends and see a new exciting place, so he found a touring band who was driving from Toronto to Calgary and hitched a ride with them. 

We fell in super love. We liked being around each other a lot and decided to do whatever it took to be around each other all the time. So we spent the rest of the spring, summer and fall in Calgary, and then left Canada to spend the winter holidays with Christian’s family and friends in Georgia. Since then, we've been working in our own respective countries and visiting each other across the border as often as we can.

Our time together has been amazing, but not without some tough life stuff along the way. There was the time Christian was denied entry to Canada due to a lack of proper visa and return plane ticket. We cried as we parted ways, not knowing when we would ever see each other again. Then there was the time Calgary flooded lots and lots, and our beautiful love nest of an apartment was destroyed. But we’ve stayed very happy, very excited to live life together and experience the world. We’ve been trying to stay in the same country together for as long as possible, but money and immigration laws make it difficult. A few months ago, Christian decided to try and apply for school in Calgary. AND GUESS WHAT?! Just last week, he found out he was accepted to the University of Calgary!! :)








For most of our lives we've felt a strong connection to Japan and Japanese culture, and for some reason we think it will play an important role in our future. It’s one of the reasons we got along so well when we first met. It’s been Ali’s dream to visit since she was 11, when she first started learning Japanese. Christian has been to Tokyo once, many years ago, and has desperately wanted to return ever since. A couple of months ago, we finally gathered together the money to afford the trip, bought plane tickets and booked our accommodations.

Our departure is date approaching quickly! But, as everything always seems to happen at once, a lot of unexpected expenses have come up. The flood last year made it exceptionally difficult to find an affordable place to live in Calgary, but Ali recently found a fantastic place to rent—though, sealing the deal meant handing over a hefty damage deposit and first month’s rent. And Christian being accepted into the University of Calgary means having to fork over some big fat tuition bucks soon. We are very fortunate, and these are expenses that we are happily paying, but their timing is kinda stinky. So, the way it’s looking now, we probably won’t get to experience very much of Japan during our two weeks there. I mean, we’ll be mainly staying in Tokyo—I don’t think it’s possible to have a BAD time in Tokyo (unless you’re arrested?), but there are SO many things we would love to see and do while we are there. Nothing crazy or lavish, no expensive meals, just modest trips and places we’ve always wanted to visit (Ghibli Museum!), and fellow artists we would like to meet and support while we are there.

This is an incredibly important and meaningful trip for both of us! Seriously, big time! So we are reaching out and asking you to help :) Even a dollar or two would be really fantastic and would mean the world to us.

And if you’re reading this, and you decide to donate nothing, we would like to extend a warm smile to you, and wish you a very beautiful day, and let you know that we really really appreciate you for checking out our page :) 


ありがとうございます！


ありがとうございます！


ありがとうございます！

story:
The short:

Be a part of sending the first ever Tourettes Without Regrets Slam Team to the 2011 National Poetry Slam in Boston. 

The long:

 Tourettes Without Regrets- The Fight Club of Underground Art  “is a bare-ass free-for-all under the guise of a poetry slam”* "Tourettes is sex, drugs, and spoken word," says show host and National Poetry Slam Champion Jamie DeWolf. "It's like a party for poets, sort of a debaucherous celebration of id. Ultimately, it's a poetry show at heart -- it's just a much more renegade form of poetry."

Tourettes is taking the irrepressible ferocity and talent it’s been bringing to the bay for 11 years to the stage in Boston for the 2011 National Poetry Slam Championships FOR THE FIRST TIME. 

Your donation will help us get 4 teammates and a manager from California to Boston and put em up in a hotel for the week of competition.  The less we have to fret about how we get there, the more we can focus on killing stages once we arrive, so every little bit helps.

This is slam history, be a part of making it.

 

About the National Poetry Slam:

 

The National Poetry Slam is America's biggest team poetry slam. Held every year since 1990, it is the definitive showcase for competitive performance poetry. Billed as "the competitive art of performance poetry," Slam was invented in Chicago in July 1986 by construction worker-turned-poet Marc Smith. It is a fast-paced competition where poets have a limited amount of time to impress judges randomly selected from the audience. Storytelling, lyricism, and stand-up  comedy all come together in what’s evolved to a modern oral tradition. This year, the 22nd annual National Poetry Slam will be held in Boston, Massachusetts, and expects to draw a record number of teams. For more information, visit http://nps2011.com. Follow NPS2011 on Twitter @nationalslam, or on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/NPS2011.

 

About the Tourettes Without Regrets team:

 

Jamie De Wolf: is a slam poet, stand up comedian, teaching artist and filmmaker from Oakland, CA. After being banned from local open mics in his hometowns of Benicia and Vallejo for his raw subject matter, vaudevillian theatrics and dark humor, he created Tourettes Without Regrets in 1999 out of revenge, to showcase the cutting edge of undeground performance. Since then, the show has become the longest running freestyle battle and the largest slam on the West Coast. It was awarded the “Best of the Bay” by the SF Guardian and continues every first thursday of the month in Oakland, CA.

Since his first slam in 1999, DeWolf (formerly known as Jamie Kennedy) won his way onto seven slam teams every year he’s competed and has since become a National Poetry Slam Champion, the Oakland and Berkeley Grand Slam Champion, a YouthSpeaks Mentor, a featured performer on HBO’s Def Poetry Jam, and has performed and lead writing workshops at over 90 universities, high schools and juvies across the U.S, to Moscow, Russia and San Quentin Penitentiary. His work has been featured on 60 Minutes, UPN and NPR.

 

Caitlin Gill: Tourettes Without Regrets 2011 Slam Champ!  People are talking about Caitlin Gill.  Most of what they’re saying has to do with how funny she is.  Caitlin has played the top comedy venues in the Bay Area and beyond (even a few places in the SF Tenderloin that used to be comedy clubs but are now abandoned buildings).  She has been a performer in SF Sketchfest since 2007, performed in the Vancouver Global Comedy Fest, was host of the 2009 SF Women’s Comedy Competition and the Ladies Room Open Mic and Showcase from 2007-2009.  Her writing has been featured in performances in SF Sketchfest and Vancouver Global Comedy fest, as well datecandy.com, and in a Believer Magazine project for 826LA. She is also Tourettes Without Regrets Featured performer and Dirty Haiku Champion.   Her style twists her personal experiences into comedy confessions that will leave you red in the face, probably from laughter.  

Stephen Meads: is a writer of things. His unmatched energy, incredible wit, and acrobatic performances have made him an integral member of the Bay Area's collaborative writing and performing ensembles since 2005, and he annually serves as one of three judges for the National Poetry Slam's legendary Nerd Slam. In addition to being a member of the Tourette's Without Regrets 2011 Poetry Slam team, Stephen has been a member of Berkeley's 2010 team, Oakland's 2009 team, as well as San Francisco's 08 and 05 team, which placed 6th in the world. Stephen's writing dances between whimsical humor, and honest revelation. He always brings excitement, and never leaves us bored.

The Poet –i-: "-i-" was born Danielle Monique Weems. The mother of four currently spends most of her free time hiding her skeletons beneath her bed because she knows that her closet is the first place most people will look. She is a native of Oakland, Ca and a member of Team Berkeley 2008 where she was labeled the "Damsel of DOOM" for her craft of bringing the darkness.

 

*Katy St Clair in the East Bay Express

story:
Outer Realm is ran by two individuals; Adam Fagundo and Scott Gasorski.

Outer Realm Apparel was actually started as Outer Realm Travels a few years ago when I (Adam) wanted to start putting on shows. I was at a Papadosio show for my birthday at State Bridge and knew right then I always wanted to do something where music was involved. As things never really took off with it, I was given a sign to do something else. My friend who lives in Michigan, Alex, was posting some pictures of shirts he was printing and I thought it was so cool so I asked if he'd print me some and if I could do a few. I did my first shirt influenced by Lotus. I did it for the April run in 2013 in Boulder, CO. April 4th is the day we consider the birth of Outer Realm Apparel because that's when we sold our first apparel and it started with Lotus. A few weeks after I started designing stuff and really thinking about it I brought the idea to Scott to see if he wanted any wholesale stuff. Instead of doing that we decided to just be business partners and work together. We quickly realized we had a lot of potential here. 

Since then we have expanded onto several other products. Not only have we continued to produce shirts, but we have designed several different pins, ventured into jewelry, art, prints, and have no plans to stop expanding any time soon. We love art, especially involving sacred geomerty, and really dig having that type of stuff on our tables. We have several close friends that help produce wraps, rings, pendants, collectible coins, guitar hangars, belt buckles, and so much more that all want to help with our movement and will shortly have a lot of new different products.

What We Need & What You Get

For Vending: We need a canopy for our booth, extension cords, vending fees, a dolly, and bins for all of our stuff. We will also probably need a few more lights, things to display our jewelry, mannequins for some of our dresses and clothes, and stuff to display all our other small products. 

Screen Printing: We honestly need everything to start screen printing ourselves. We plan to start small and work our way up. Starting off with probably only a 2-3 color press and hoping to get to several colors within the year. 

With this we also plan on finally launching our website. We don't plan on using it just for selling but we plan to also start a music blog and review as well. 

Ideally we'd need like $5,000 to get everything that we really want. Raising $2,000 is a good start to not only pay for the few festivals we can vend this summer and pay for the gear we need, but it will also help us get the beginning parts of our own screen printing equipment. 

For helping us you can receive a lot of different ORA original products as well as knowing you are helping start a movement not just some company. 


The Impact

We already give back to the ones that support us with giveaways but also by letting them put art and other things on our table and helping produce projects they can not afford. Once we start screen printing we want to donate to homeless shelters and give part of our profits to other organizations we think are important like arts and music in schools and clean water for those who have none. We hope to start conscious festivals and shows that aren't just about the music but also things like consciousness, yoga, the people, and art. 

We are really trying to start going local with everything from our business cards but also to our supplier of all of our products. Though we aren't fully local and American made yet, we are really striving to do that. We are hoping to also start having hemp and organic apparel.  

Our ultimate goal with ORA is still put on shows and festivals in the future and have our own store. We honestly think we have a real chance to help change a lot of what's wrong with the world through ORA and have the drive to start a movement. As we are always helping our friends get their art out there and give stuff back to our the music community, but also just honestly sending out good vibes not only when we vend but just in general. A lot of why Outer Realm was started was to help our friends, family, community, and honestly the world. By helping get our friends beautiful art out there but to also help the community by going local, but also donating and helping with fundraisers and events. 


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Go on facebook and like and share our page
  • Just spread the word about our company and the cause.

story:
My name is Kent Latimer. I am a sculptor and, now, a jewelry designer. My journey started twenty-seven years ago, when I was suspended from the Virginia Military Institute and returned to my home town in North Carolina. I was academically ruined, demoralized, and casting about aimlessly, unsure of what to do next.

Then, on a morning that I still remember in detail, I was at work in an industrial supply warehouse when the idea to teach myself how to paint suddenly popped into my head. It was such a clear calling, and for the first time in my life, I felt a sense of direction. Everything snowballed from there. I returned to school and graduated with honors, with a BFA in sculpture. I sold out my student show and have had many more moments of success, as well as enthusiastic collectors and supporters of my earlier work.

But from that fateful morning, I felt that I had been put on a specific path of self-discovery. I've always had faith that I was working towards a moment when mature work, timing and opportunity would all converge and that only then would I be ready to run with what I had.

That moment finally came just before Christmas 2011. A huge job had just cancelled on me at the last minute. I was despondent, but I had a ton of time on my hands. On a whim, I combined two of my most recent materials to create my first plastic jewelry, and I saw the life I had been waiting for right in front of me. It was an amazing moment of recognition. I was already slated to show my zip tie sculptures at a gallery during the citywide Fiber Philadelphia biennial in March 2012, and my jewelry turned out to be the hit of the show. I worked on commissions all month, sought out advice from friends in the field, and began setting things in motion to make this my full-time career. I'm seeking to raise money to offset the costs of:

-Designing and building a new website and printing new business cards

-Time and materials to create a cherry-picked body of work and build inventory

-Travel to select cities that I see as viable markets and where I have established support networks - Houston, TX; Nashville, TN; Chicago; and New York to start. In each of these cities I will continue to work, develop networks and seek venues.

As a contractor (my day job), I was financially ruined by the Great Recession. I'm now a full-time gypsy. Eventually, I would like to be able to settle down again and have an established studio, so any amount I raise will have a huge impact by giving me the financial power to bring this vision to life. All contributions, regardless of size, will be personally acknowledged! I will always be eternally grateful for the strength and faith it has taken to get me to this point. Now I just need a little help to make it happen. Thank you!

 

A couple of extra notes:

The perks are for this incentive only and will not reflect future retail price.

For 99.999% of you, this is not going to be everyday jewelry. This is a piece you will wear to a smashing event. It is also a work of art so even if you never intend to wear it, but you want to support me and get something for your money, you can always display it as such!

For the moment, you can see more:
zip tie sculpture and additional jewelry at xipping.tumblr.com
bio and history at kentlatimer.com
story_txt:
My name is Kent Latimer. I am a sculptor and, now, a jewelry designer. My journey started twenty-seven years ago, when I was suspended from the Virginia Military Institute and returned to my home town in North Carolina. I was academically ruined, demoralized, and casting about aimlessly, unsure of what to do next.
Then, on a morning that I still remember in detail, I was at work in an industrial supply warehouse when the idea to teach myself how to paint suddenly popped into my head. It was such a clear calling, and for the first time in my life, I felt a sense of direction. Everything snowballed from there. I returned to school and graduated with honors, with a BFA in sculpture. I sold out my student show and have had many more moments of success, as well as enthusiastic collectors and supporters of my earlier work.
But from that fateful morning, I felt that I had been put on a specific path of self-discovery. I've always had faith that I was working towards a moment when mature work, timing and opportunity would all converge and that only then would I be ready to run with what I had.
That moment finally came just before Christmas 2011. A huge job had just cancelled on me at the last minute. I was despondent, but I had a ton of time on my hands. On a whim, I combined two of my most recent materials to create my first plastic jewelry, and I saw the life I had been waiting for right in front of me. It was an amazing moment of recognition. I was already slated to show my zip tie sculptures at a gallery during the citywide Fiber Philadelphia biennial in March 2012, and my jewelry turned out to be the hit of the show. I worked on commissions all month, sought out advice from friends in the field, and began setting things in motion to make this my full-time career. I'm seeking to raise money to offset the costs of:
-Designing and building a new website and printing new business cards
-Time and materials to create a cherry-picked body of work and build inventory
-Travel to select cities that I see as viable markets and where I have established support networks - Houston, TX; Nashville, TN; Chicago; and New York to start. In each of these cities I will continue to work, develop networks and seek venues.
As a contractor (my day job), I was financially ruined by the Great Recession. I'm now a full-time gypsy. Eventually, I would like to be able to settle down again and have an established studio, so any amount I raise will have a huge impact by giving me the financial power to bring this vision to life. All contributions, regardless of size, will be personally acknowledged! I will always be eternally grateful for the strength and faith it has taken to get me to this point. Now I just need a little help to make it happen. Thank you!
 
A couple of extra notes:
The perks are for this incentive only and will not reflect future retail price.
For 99.999% of you, this is not going to be everyday jewelry. This is a piece you will wear to a smashing event. It is also a work of art so even if you never intend to wear it, but you want to support me and get something for your money, you can always display it as such!
For the moment, you can see more:zip tie sculpture and additional jewelry at xipping.tumblr.combio and history at kentlatimer.com

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Nora Delgado and I am a volunteer for Encuentro Latino Community Art Center. I found out about this organization about 18 months ago, and since then I realize the undeniable level of passion and commitment from Miguel Angel Rios – the founder, and the rest of the volunteers that keep fueling this organization with their in-kind donations.

Encuentro Latino was founded in 2007 by Mexican artist, Miguel Angel Rios with the mission to provide a space for upcoming Latino Artists. Over the years it has evolved into an artistic community outlet for children, teenagers and adults alike, offering art, dance, and baile folkorico classes; organizing free family events and serving as a cultural mecca in Lynwood, CA and its surrounding communities.

Since its doors opened, Encuentro Latino has impacted the lives of 100,000 people!!! It offers a yearly average of 200 art workshops, caters to 4,000 students, organizes 8 art & cultural events reaching 2,000 community members per event, and recruits over 1,000 volunteers throughout the year; this impact cannot be overlooked!

What We Need & What You Get

I have worked with many wonderful non-profit organizations that I support to this day, however,  I can genuinely say that Encuentro Latino is what I call a grassroots movement. Every month Miguel, his wife Karin Guerra, his brother Fernando Rios, and the volunteer team devote hundreds of labor hours and donate from their personal funds knowing that they are positively impacting at-risk youth and providing a cultural space for the community. 

Your donations will not only ensure that the Art Gallery remains open throughout 2013 but it will help us secure the operating costs of upgrading from a single room to a Community Art Center in Lynwood. Our limited space does not allow us to adequately serve the community and offer dance classes which are highly solicited. In order to continue offering affordable classes to the community at large we need your donations to subsidize the operating costs. We are currently in the process of officially becoming a non-profit 501 c(3), this will allow us to become eligible for state and federal grants but until then we kindly ask you to donate.

Help us upgrade from one room to a community center and impact 20,000 people throughout 2013. The following is the breakdown of the operating expenses for one year:

***As you will see this does not include a salary or monetary compensation for Miguel, the volunteer instructors, and all the supporting artists that share their skills & talent every single day.

  • $16,000  (rent, utilities & insurance)
  • $20,000  (art materials for all in house and community event students – reaching 4,000)
  • $8,000 to (tents, chairs, tables, & sound equipment for 8 FREE community events (2,000 expected guests)

*Our fundraiser will culminate with a Cultural Art Celebration on Sunday, April 21st,  2013 at Plaza de la Raza. Featuring local artists, musicians, vendors, ethnic food, and lots more! We hope you can join the celebration, it’s completely FREE!

Impact

Encuentro Latino represents the heart of the Lynwood community. It is here, that at-risk children are offered the opportunity to freely express their emotions through art, learn about specific artistic techniques, harness their passion, and develop their innate talents. It is here, that volunteer teachers become mentors to students and parents. It is here that thousands have witnessed the healing of physical, emotional, and spiritual wounds. It is here, that the right brain breaks free from the left while reaching into the heart and manifesting a vision for a better tomorrow.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially to this cause, we are still grateful for taking the time to learn more about us. There are many ways you can become a part of this movement:

  • Share this campaign with friends via email or social media sites.
  • Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter.
  • Volunteer your time with us:
    • offering a class
    • helping other instructors
    • mentoring students/parents
    • assist at any of our events
    • Connect us  with anyone that can donate their services (such as a lawyer) and help us throughout the process of becoming a 501 c(3).

THANK YOU!!!

story:
Friends, Artists, Community:

Epoch Opus

Epoch Opus is beginning, and this beginning will be yours and mine. I owe a lot to my friends and family and to the city of San Francisco. It has always been there for me since the first day I opened my Gallery in North Beach. My friends, family, and colleagues have supported me, and I have supported them. This support brings me to Epoch Opus, and a beginning moment to embark on my most ambitious and challenging art exhibition to date. And just like before, I am not alone. We are a team of artists, curators, galleries and supporters. 

Epoch Opus is fine art exhibition presented by Art Meets Architecture that features collaborating artists Anthony Aversano and Isaac Saavedra.  Other contributing artists include, Sami Naegu and  Aureilus Tishlarish . Epoch Opus consists of fine art paintings, installation sculptures, and new art technologies. This exhibition features two large scale 24-foot murals presented next to unique lighting and installation art. Smaller paintings and prints will be included in the exhibition as well. The Opus represents past, hope for the future, but focuses on the present moment in time, or Epoch. Anthony and Isaac’s Postmodernism vs. Deconstructivism works recalls imagery and imagination from their surrounding world inside and out, and looks to generate an exhibition that evokes emotion and provides inspiration to its viewers. Both Aversano and Saavedra have long been on the gallery and art exhibition circuit. Anthony's, A. Aversano Galleria in North Beach was a true representation for the rich North Beach Art Community, as well as Isaac's commanding Gamma Space in Oakland. The last major collaboration between Anthony and Isaac, titled, Destin Manifesto, exhibited in San Francisco, Oakland, & Los Angeles. 

Epcoh Opus will open in San Francisco and travel to Los Angeles next with plans to exhibit outside of California and the United States.

We are committed to getting this art project funded. The estimated budget for this show is $12,000 dollars. Including rent, materials, and marketing. 

I see this exhibition as the greatest opportunity we have yet been presented with. Please help us make it a reality! Please help with any means you can whether it is by contributing $25 or $100 or emailing this out to your art friends who might be interested in supporting arts. Or by promoting the show and this sponsorship on your facebook page.

 

One Million Thanks,

Anthony Aversano
