story:
Support the reprinting of a true American style book:          

                          “AUTHENTIC HAIR™”        

Our story                                       

AUTHENTIC HAIR™ is the first American-style book of extraordinary photos and affirming poems that celebrate the beauty and the versatility of Natural Hair; first self-published by industry innovator, Ademola Mandella in 2001, this book is now considered an American classic by collectors. Although it is currently out of print, it is still in high demand on Amazon.com and independent bookstores across America.

 AUTHENTIC HAIR™ is a beautiful American style book designed for anyone who loves art, style and culture!

Mandella has been at the forefront of the natural hair care industry for over 25 years, as a stylist, salon owner, and teacher. He is committed to motivating the community and educating the next generation of natural hair professionals about the beauty and versatility of natural hair and locks. (www.ademolamandella.com).

The goal of this crowdfunding campaign is to raise $10,000 to print the first paperback edition of AUTHENTIC HAIR™. 

We are asking for your support in printing the 10th anniversary edition of this genuine American style book.

No contribution is too large or too small. And, each contribution will help toward reaching our goal.  As a gesture of appreciation for your support, Mandella is offering special perks that we think you will enjoy.

The success of this fundraiser will enable the book to be available online in the fall of 2012 at:www.authentichairbook.com , www.amazon.com, and at selected retail salons and specialty shops. 

About the book

To celebrate this 10th anniversary edition, we’ve added some new photos of beautiful natural hairstyles, featuring today’s most innovative natural style techniques including: Interlocks, Sister Locks and Transitional Twist-Outs. All of the photos are now featured in timeless sepia tone. The cover has been updated to a rich emerald green with bold fuchsia accents.

 The book features:

· A foreword by “The Cosby Show’s” Malcolm Jamal Warner

· Classic natural hair styles creation by 20 of New York’s premier, natural hair     stylists

· An exquisite selection of beautifully diverse models, brilliantly photographed by master photographer: Preston Phillips

· Inspiring and affirming natural hair poems and prose by 50 of New York’s most dynamic poets

· An updated comprehensive glossary and essential information about the care of natural hair and locks

     


Impact

Thanks to the Indiegogo crowdfunding site and social networking, we can finally raise the funds needed to print an initial order of 1000 paperback editions of AUTHENTIC HAIR™.  We intend to formally launch the new edition in the fall 2012.

Following the launch, we are planning special book signing/poetry reading around the New York City tri-state area. The book will be available on www.authentichairbook.com, www.amazon.com and at selected retail salons and specialty shops.

Objectives

The immediate goal is to print and launch this authentic American Style book!                    

Mandella’s ultimate goal is to raise the awareness of all people about the timeless beauty of natural hair and locks. This book is an amazing teaching tool for the salon, home, and classroom.

What we need & what you get

We need $10,000 for the printing of 1000 of the first paperback edition of AUTHENTIC HAIR™.

When you give to this campaign, you will be added to our network of supporters and all the perks that come with it.

We are also asking you to join our network of enthusiastic supporters by volunteering as a special assistant at book signing/poetry events.

Volunteers will be rewarded with special perks; T-shirt, poster and signed copy of AUTHENTIC HAIR™.

Other ways you can help

We are asking you to share this campaign with friends and family who are lovers of art/style and American culture; by Email, Twitter and Facebook.

We are inviting salon owners, independent stylists, owners of book stores and art galleries to host an AUTHENTIC HAIR™ book-signing/poetry reading event.    Email info@authentichairbook.com. 


To make a contribution

Making a contribution is easy! You can donate by check—it will count toward our $10,000 campaign goal; although it will not be reflected on this IndieGoGo campaign page. Make the check payable to Naturthentic Hair Care System and include AUTHENTIC HAIR™ campaign on the memo line. Include your mailing address and send your check to the following address:

Authentic Hair

C/o Ademola Mandella

610 Madison Street, Suite #2

Brooklyn, NY 11221

If you prefer, you can also use PayPal to make your contribution. However, please note that PayPal contributions will not be reflected on the IndieGoGo campaign total. If you have any questions, please email info@authentichairbook.com or call Mandella at 718.636.4485.

Your generous contribution will have a direct impact on printing the 10th anniversary first paperback edition of this American classic, AUTHENTIC HAIR™.  Thanks!

story:
We are raising funds for indigenous artists in the sierra of Oaxaca, Mexico to make a short film about their lives and their art.  The Puech Ikots artists collective was founded in Oaxaca, Mexico in 2009 to provide opportunities for these artists to improve their economic situation while also preserving their artistic heritage, and to share the culture and art of Oaxaca with a larger audience. The phrase "Puech Ikots" means "words of our people" in the indigenous Huave language of Oaxaca.

The collective creates alebrijes, which are brightly colored, traditional Mexican folk art sculptures of animals and fantastical creatures. The artists carve these sculptures out of wood and then paint them by hand.  Puech Ikots is fiscally sponsored in the United States by Cuentos Foundation in Chicago, IL, and their art is sold in both Oaxaca and Chicago. (If you would like to make a tax-deductable donation to this project via Cuentos Foundation, that is definitely possible!)

The finished film will be shown in Oaxaca and in Chicago to promote and support Puech Ikots. The artists are very eager to do this!  They created an 8-minute video about 2 years ago, with support from people in the United States (the Youtube link showing 2 minutes of this video is included in this campaign). They had no experience whatsoever with making videos, and creating the video was a very empowering experience for them.  The artists who have joined the collective since then were inspired by the video and want to create their own longer version, to share not only their art form but their lives and their community.

The funds from this campaign will go to pay for food and travel costs for the 2 main organizers of the collective to travel from Oaxaca City to the Oaxacan sierra, and spend a week visiting collective members and filming.  Any funds received above what is needed for the travel costs of the film will be given to the artists collective to buy artistic supplies (copal wood and paint), and/or better quality carving tools (as you can see from the video, the artists work with machetes and rough blades).

UPDATE: We are so grateful for the outpouring of support and for having reached our goal!  Some of the artists of Puech Ikots have been monitoring the progress of this campaign from Oaxaca via the internet and are very moved by the response we have had.  So THANK YOU!  Anyone who sees this campaign and feels moved to donate, please do, because although we have reached our $500 goal there is still so much that is needed for this project.  

The artists will use at least $100 (20% of the $500 we have raised so far) to buy paint, wood, and tools.  At least 20% of what we raise over $500 will go directly to the artists for that purpose.  But there are still supplies that must be purchased in Oaxaca in order to make the video recording- for example a tripod to hold the camera steady, and reflectors to maximize the light when recording the video (the surroundings will be very rustic, with natural light only, so reflectors must be used to maximize the sunlight/firelight that is being used for recording).  So, any donations beyond this point will be deeply appreciated and definitely put to good use.  Every donation makes the collective's lives easier.  Thank you again for your interest in this campaign, and please spread the word!

story:
Who/What is JAHA+LOU?

JAHA+LOU is a collaboration between two queer witch priestesses: jenstar and her aura (JAHA) and lou lamotte. We are co-creating a healing ceremony / group sound healing session / sacred art installation / multi-media performance piece that we are taking on tour through 6 cities: 

  • Denver, Colorado
  • Santa Fe, New Mexico
  • Albuquerque, New Mexico
  • Tucson, Arizona
  • Los Angeles, California
  • Oakland, California

Funds raised from this campaign will cover:

  • Gas
  • Airfare (for Lou who is based out of Portland Oregon to Denver)
  • Food 
  • Printing shirts/totes to sell on tour
  • Design Services (to pay the artist drawing our images)
  • Materials to make Essences/Medicine on tour (bottles, alcohol, glycerine etc)
  • Materials for the Installation
  • Space/Venue Rental for 6 cities 

Our Dream

This September when we launch our tour is also our 10 year friend anniversary!

For the last six of those ten years we have been dreaming about combining our passions and our work. We knew they fit together, we just didn't know how. And so we waited and dreamed, went on long walks and planned hundreds of different kinds of shows and tours and visions. We followed our separate paths confident that someday they would merge again. And finally, that moment is here! As Jenstar worked on her sound healing work in Denver and Lou continued Priestess training and her art practice in Portland, the paths finally connected as we realized our vision of this tour: to share the power of sound and our voices with each other to create healing while being supported in a sacred installation altar. To blur the lines of a healing session and a musical show. To blur the lines of showing art while it is in process, letting it be shaped by the people around it and the experiences we share together. To not totally know what is going to happen, but to trust that what is supposed to be, will be. 
We are so excited to share this unique experience with you! To create it with you and let it expand and grow as we do.  Your support will directly affect our ability to rent spaces to hold our event. Many of these spaces require a deposit and your contribution will help us secure these places, as well as put gas in the car and pay for promotion materials to help get the word out. 
About us:
Jenstar and her Aura or JAHA, is a queer witch priestess who offers sound healing via the frequencies of her powerful voice. She believes in the power of vibration to help people tune into their truths, break through blocks, and activate/live your potential and purpose. Drawing on her background as a theater performer, musician and singer, she sees ritual and ceremony as a space to express ourselves fully. After working with the land and faerie energies for 10 years in Portland, Oregon, she now offers her healing services in Denver, Colorado. Though she misses the watery green of the NW, the expansive sun and rocky mountains is just what she needs to fully launch forth her business, JAHA Vocal Sound Healing. 

Lou LaMotte is a Queer Witch Priestess in training at the Blue Iris Mystery School in Portland, Oregon. She sees patterns in all things, from the feelings we feel to the connectedness of all that is, and loves to find them, untangle them, and purposefully reconnect them. She loves helping others do that too. She weaves magic, ritual, and healing into her art practice in the creation of installations, book making, and fiber works. She is a dream analyzer, an animal communicator, and a maker of things. She is listens to the wind and to the water. She tends a home and the land in Portland, Oregon, where she hopes to someday soon understand the squirrels that climb around on the Elm tree.

What We Need & What You Get

Estimated costs:

$200 airfare round trip 

$500  gas 3300 miles 

$700 food 14 days at $50/day  

$400 printing shirts/totes etc merch making 

$300 design services: logo, shirt images  

$100 materials for essences + sprays

$150 thread/yarn/rope/installation materials

$600 space rental x 6 cities (varies of course)

$200 Miscellaneous costs 

$200 indiegogo fee

 $3300

In exchange for your financial help we have many gifts to offer in exchange. Living in this world that we do, we are unable to fuel the car and rent spaces in trade, and so we are offering that trade here. In exchange for $50 Lou will hand bind you a beautiful journal, or for $10 we will hand paint you a post card and send it to you from tour! Real mail! Please check out the perks we are offering! 

We are looking at this as a sort of market place where you can purchase some of the amazing things we have to offer while also knowing that your money is going directly to helping us realize our dreams! 

If we don't realize our goal, we are still going on tour, so every bit helps. It might be a harder road to travel, but we know that we are called to this work! The bulk of our funds are going towards gas and venue rentals. In some cities we are renting out yoga or dance studios and they require deposits, and your support can help use secure these spaces for our tour. 

With your help we know we can make our goal! If you are unable to financially help, we totally understand, but we would love help sharing this campaign and letting people in your community know about it.

It is really so beautiful that with just a little bit we can all help each other live our dreams! 

Thank you so much! We send you so much love and gratitude!

Xoxo JAHA + Lou 

PS. To experience JAHA Vocal Sound Healing, you can hear JAHA Meditate at https://jenstarandheraura.bandcamp.com/album/ja...

Denver, Colorado
Santa Fe, New Mexico
Albuquerque, New Mexico
Tucson, Arizona
Los Angeles, California
Oakland, California

Gas

story:
This is our first fundraiser of the 2013/14 season and we are asking for your support of our 2014 Artist Fund. The 2014 Artist Fund will provide funds for producing interdisciplinary artists around the city. The money raised from this appeal helps us directly support these NYC-based artists like Bill Shannon (pictured above)

Since our last fall fundraiser ITE has been on the move. Due to your generosity we have been able to offer three NYC-based arts groups space grants, and are holding monthly cultural events throughout the city. So far we have held 2 sold out artists showcases and two successful board cultivation events and there is much more to come.

ITE exists to support groundbreaking, emerging artists by providing financial and promotional support in the shape of space grants, exhibitions and performance opportunities to help artists complete and premier new works in low-cost, high quality venues around Manhattan. ITE’s shows and performances are intimate and offer an up-close view of professional New York artists at the peak of their creative powers. 

As a not-for-profit organization we rely primarily on private donations. Your support is indispensable and your donation will help us in pursuing our mission: to provide a holistic arts experience from inception to exhibition for NYC based artists.

We hope that we can count on your support!!! Please consider making a donation at one of the following levels. Thank you.

story:
Who You're Helping:

My name is Filip Kostic, I'm a 20 year old  artist residing in San Pedro California and  I absolutely love to draw. It's as simple as  that. I grew up drawing as a hobby, had  no idea I would be here pursuing it as a  life long career years later. But here I am  now, throwing it all on the line and giving  my dream a go.

I was recently accepted by my dream  school, Art Center College of Design, as  an Illustration major for Spring 2014. As you could imagine, opening that envelope was one of the happiest moments of my young life! The opportunity to learn from some of the greatest creators currently walking this Earth, and to grow alongside some amazing artists is now open to me so long as I accept it. Truly a gift!

Why Should You Donate? Perks and More!

Good question! Tuition per semester at Art Center is $18,200 not including books/supplies/expenses. They estimate about $27,000 with cost of living, gas, books, and all included.. A hefty price for anyone, regardless of your financial background! I've been able to dwindle my tuition costs down to about $7,500 a semester through scholarships and federal loans, but am currently ineligible for any private loans, meaning I have to come up with that remaining lump on my own (with the help of my family.) 


This is where you come in! In short: any donation you make will help me and my family afford the first semester's tuition, but in the long run your contribution is an investment in my art, you are making a statement that you believe in me and my art. You are investing in my future! 

But "my future" is so vague! Your donations have immediate physical gratifications! I've set up an assortment of perk tiers for donations that range from prints, to paintings, to original illustrations! Along with each one of these one of a kind pieces of my work, you get my eternal gratitude. Most of the perks are already completed pieces of work (including prints, paintings, and original illustrations), although I am offering some "to be made" art too. 

The first I am offering is a portrait of the donor! You pick out the photo and I'll do a portrait of you in my style. These portraits will vary from person to person, but will more than likely be done in a combination of graphite and charcoal and will stylistically resemble my self portrait I did in charcoal shown here (again, will vary from individual to individual.)

The largest donation perk is the most personal one. I will give to you my Self Portrait. This piece is incredibly personal and means a lot to me, it has opened up an immense amount of opportunity for me and has taught me a lot about myself. The piece is 42"x76" approximately and it is done on 140lb watercolor paper in graphite. It was featured in the El Camino Personal Tales gallery as well as my focus piece of my entrance portfolio for Art Center. By making this donation you would receive something that has made an enormous impact on me as a person and my life, you would have a very large (quite literally) piece of me!

The second offer I have is a piece that we essentially will work on together. We will work as a boiling pot together in which we will pour our ideas and concepts into and come up with a one of a kind piece just for you. You will be involved throughout the process and will receive updates on your piece as it progresses!


It is important to note that a lot of my perks are limited, that means first come first serve type basis. Once I run out of the perks I can't make more. This is mostly due to the time constraints that making a lot of these pieces creates. As much as I'd LOVE to do something for each and every donation, there isn't enough time! I hope this doesn't discourage donors from contributing!


How Your Donation Helps:

Even the smallest donation helps! Honestly, even by donating $1 you are helping me a great deal! That's 1 less dollar my family and I have to worry about this semester! I don't know how much money I'l be able to pull together through this, but I know that every cent will help TREMENDOUSLY!

On a much more substantial level, your donation is a direct way of showing your support. It shows that you believe in something greater than me, because ultimately, I am going to Art School to gain the technical skills to share my message with the world. A message the will hopefully leave the world in a better state than it was before. 

Not to worry though, if you can't donate you can still help out! The easiest way you can help is by sharing with a friend. Help me get the word out! I believe the website has the option to share this with a handful of social medias through a click, or you can copy the link directly.. I mean, you guys know how to work the internet :P 

Thank you all so much for the continual support and love, I can't articulate how much I appreciate you all and how thankful I am!

If you need to contact me for whatever reason, message me on Facebook or Email!

filip.kostic93@gmail.com
www.facebook.com/filip.kostic93

View more of my work and daily shenanigans on Instagram
@filipkostic

story:
Short Summary

Hello all! My name is Dale Dupre' and I'm a 19 year old San Diego native with a bit of an issue. Currently I attend the Alberta College of Art and Design in Calgary, Alberta, Canada as a first year traditional art and jewelry student. I am now facing a situation considering money which is why I'm asking you all for your help. I have received a half-ride scholarship to ACAD along with financial aid, but I still fall short with funds. By being an international student, I am only able to pull out federal loans which has caused myself to pay the remaining funds out of pocket, which at this moment is not feasible. I have been practicing my craft for 16 years of my life, and this campaign will help me not only make it up to Canada, but will get me closer to becoming a professional artist. 

What We Need & What You Get

For this campaign, I'm very appreciative for whatever amount I can make especially in the economy we're currently in. This $2,000 campaign will all go towards getting myself up to Canada and paying off the remaining tuition I have left for this upcoming semester which starts in August. I will need to raise about $500 for my plane ticket to get to ACAD from San Diego, then $1500 will be used to pay off the last bit of my tuition. If this can be achieved, I will continue to attend ACAD in the fall and will be one step closer to completing my degree.

Challenges

Through the remainder of the summer break, I will be working and selling artwork, but I'm relying on the last $2000 to get me all settled before returning to ACAD in the fall.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

My artwork is viewable on my tumblr account at: http://dupre-d.tumblr.com/
For any interest in commissions/work opportunities contact me at feelerdale@yahoo.com
Once again, thank you all for the love and support, and with your help I can return to ACAD in the fall!

story:
Our story...

Heart Phoenix is a group of veteran burners, artists, and creators with a unified mission of creating an experience for people to open their hearts and connect with one another through art & music.

In 2013 we brought a bold vision to Black Rock City in hopes of spreading love and amazing music across the playa. The project was a success and we left with a overwhelming feeling of gratitude to the people who helped us along the way, and who danced with us from sunrise to sunset.


Our intent for 2014...

From the day we left the playa we have been dreaming, planning, and constructing an improved design intended for Burning Man 2014. With our new location at 9:30 & Esplanade we plan on making additions to our camp as well as upgrades to the Heart Phoenix bus.

Our Esplanade-facing space will include a standalone art piece with shaded structures for day events as well as a Dome for daily morning yoga classes, workshops, and night time sanctuary. We are upgrading the lighting on our bus to enhance the rising Heart Phoenix emblem on top, which serves as a beacon for our project and camp. We are in the process of upgrading the design for our bus to continue the experience all the way around our mobile structure. With these additions we will be greatly enhancing our home base events as well as our excursions into the open playa for day & night escapades.

At our events in San Francisco over the past year, a lot of you have asked how you could help. Now is your chance to make Heart Phoenix more beautiful than ever. With your contribution to Heart Phoenix we can realize the experience we wish to bring to black rock city and it’s patrons of open minded people like you. 


What we need to raise money for…

  • Design: We are upgrading the design and lighting on the back-facing side of the vehicle with a beautiful new motif (see below). 

  • Lighting: A big lighting upgrade to increase illumination of the Phoenix at night and to enhance musical performances by DJ’s and live performers. We will be adding 4 moving-head robotic lights, lasers, and additional fixed lighting to make Heart Phoenix really pop at night.
  • Restoration and Maintenance: Additionally, our 40-year old British double-decker needed some additional love this year in the form of maintenance and upgrades. 
  • Transport: Finally, we are also funding the transportation needed to bring Heart Phoenix from SF to the playa this year. 


How you can help…

This year we still need to raise $10,000 to bring back this immense work of mobile art and sound to the playa.

Please consider being a contributor to our campaign, and help us bring a magical experience back to Burning Man for you in 2014. 

Love & Gratitude, 

The Heart Phoenix Crew

The 2014 Heart Phoenix T-shirt design!


Contribution Gifts...







The Heart Phoenix crew appreciates you all!
 
------------------------------------------------------------------------
If you cant make a donation at this time, please consider sharing this with your friends and family of burners on all your social networks.
------------------------------------------------------------------------

story:
Who Am I and Where Am I Going?


My name Is Stefan Gonzales and I am currently a freshmen at Cornish College of The Arts In Seattle, I am here to study photography from a fine arts stance. There are so many opportunities I have here but my education can only go so far. This year, The Society for Photographic Education is holding their convention in Chicago IL.This convention is full of guest speakers and various other lectures from the photographic community.

In addition to all of this there is a Student portfolio critique by many professional photographers this is self is worth the entire trip. My work will examined by fresh new people with massive experience.


What I Need & What You Get


A break down of the funds needed goes as so:
 
-Flight-400$

-Rooming-200$

story_txt:
Who Am I and Where Am I Going?
My name Is Stefan Gonzales and I am currently a freshmen at Cornish College of The Arts In Seattle, I am here to study photography from a fine arts stance. There are so many opportunities I have here but my education can only go so far. This year, The Society for Photographic Education is holding their convention in Chicago IL.This convention is full of guest speakers and various other lectures from the photographic community. In addition to all of this there is a Student portfolio critique by many professional photographers this is self is worth the entire trip. My work will examined by fresh new people with massive experience.
What I Need & What You Get
A break down of the funds needed goes as so: -Flight-400$-Rooming-200$-Convention Price-165$-Food ext-150$Although I many not reach all of my funds in time all the money will help me on my journey to go. If you help me out you can recieve many perks such as hand made work of mine that may be worth something someday if you help!
The Impact
In addition to all of this there is a Student portfolio critique by many professional photographers this is self is worth the entire trip. My work will examined by fresh new people with massive experience.

story:
What's Typecase?

Typecase Industries is a tight-knit design firm thought up and executed by three close friends. Based out of Washington DC, TCI is the cumulative aspiration to be the bosses we’ve always wanted. Specializing in letterpress, we offer full-scale design services and letterpress printing services for creative, inspired, like-minded individuals.

Our goal is to raise funds to move into a new (to be determined) location.... We are currently housed in a building of artists studios, but have definitely outgrown our space. In our new space, we will be able to:

  • offer more community workshops, including events for educators and students
  • participate and host community-wide art events
  • offer press and studio rental time
  • increase the amount and variety of our workshops
  • grow as a business

What We Need & What You Get

The money we're raising is going into any build-out costs and the moving expenses for a new location... these presses are heavy ya'll!! Anything after those expenses will go towards new and exciting equipment like a foil stamping machine, drill press, plate maker and tons of new type!! If we don't reach our entire goal, the money will still be put towards the building, and we will supplement the rest with loans.

From prints and cards to workshops and wedding suites, for your financial support, we've got a ton of great perks. Donate the full amount and we'll literally throw you a party in our new space!

The Impact

Since we started TCI a little over a year ago, business has been soaring! Your contribution will help us grow even more.

We believe that we are more than just a business and we are looking for a space that will help us engage with the DC community. In our new space, we will be able to offer more workshops - including letterpress, screenprinting and binding - as well as provide studio space for guest artists to run workshops, such as calligraphy and papermaking. We are also looking into some large community printing events as well as partnering with DC area schools to inspire and introduce young adults to the world of printmaking and discuss what its like to create and operate your own business.

We have never asked for financial contributions before, and have started our business with no loans and no debt. We are hoping that our past year of success will convince you all to believe in us as we take this huge step forward.

Other Ways You Can Help

Short on cash? We understand - so are we! Here are some other great ways you can support us:

  • Spread the word about our campaign!
  • Come by and see us at the DCMeetMarket the first Saturday of every month on P Street... just around the corner from Logan Circle (or) at the new and awesome District Flea every Saturday from now through October 19th!

We're so grateful for the support we've had in the DC, letterpress and art communities! We are looking forward to many more years of bringing art to the District!


Special Thanks

A big huge thanks goes to our families and friends for supporting us over the past few years!

  • Mother Grits made our amazing video
  • Music by Mirepoix (made especially for us!)
  • The lovely still of us is by Lena Lendagger (above and in the video!)

story:
First of all,

ULR is NEVER abstract. If you can't see any realistic figure, please step back or have your eyes half closed. The feature changes suddenly!

About ULR

The beginning was in 2006 when I started "Mozaiko," the early version, and still the base of ULR, as a business. Until then I was a secretariat of an NPO. I was running around for art & artists nearby. If it had been successful, I would still be content to be a secretariat with the NPO.

  • I thought that art needs to earn money more by itself.
  • I decided to begin an experiment using my skill.
  • Exchanging works with money taught me a lot about life.

Products were made and sold through collaboration with some companies. By the way, to make "Mozaiko," I always need a strong concentration. That made me, I think, a painter in fact. When I stood in front of a canvas in 2012 for the first time in 25 years, I realized that I didn't see things like I used to, I didn't paint things like I used to, any more. Later I made my debut at an art gallery.

  • It was in 2013 that "Mozaiko" evolved to ULR.
  • ULR is a painting system which allows various features based on the same motif.
  • In 2015 I applied for patent in Japan, which was received this year, in 2017.
  • I want to also take out patent in the U.S. next year.

What We Need & What You Get

I have to raise money for taking out a patent in the U.S. This is the reason I'm here. For you, I'll make screen prints and posters. Of course I'll also sell them in Japanese galleries. I'll do all I can do. If you're interested in my idea and activity, please buy! That will push me up to the next stage.

  • The screen print has 3 variations. The features/surfaces differ, but the motif is same.
  • The screen prints are limited to 30 each: 20 for the U.S. and other countries, 10 for Japan.
  • The poster has 3 versions. The features/patterns differ, but the motif is same.
  • The posters are a special version "for crowdfunding" this time only.

 

May I talk a little bit about what I'm thinking?

Do you believe that sometimes poor eyesights can see more clearly than good ones?  Don't you think "less," in many senses, can really be "more" than ever today? Our brains are full of mysteries. When I'm painting, I always remember Japanese Zen or Haiku culture. This is never an exaggeration. I hope for the day when we can talk about the real meaning of "culture/cultivation" with some discoveries in our hands.

 

Back to the practical issue,

If you are a potential agent, client, investor, or some kind of professional, feel free to contact me. By May, 2018 I must complete an English translation of my patent and application in the U.S. I need any and all help. Below is my patent information.

  • International Application No.: PCT/JP2016/085108
  • Pub. No.: WO/2017/094641

Other Ways You Can Help

Besides contributing, you are welcome to follow, share, and tweet. If you have a friend, or a friend of a friend, working in a media company, introducing ULR to them would be great pleasure. If you are kind enough, praying, singing, or dancing for ULR might also change something! Anything is OK, please. In Japanese, "Yoroshiku Onegai Itashimasu!"

http://www.mozaiko.info/
https://www.youtube.com/user/ondo0000/
https://twitter.com/ondo0000/

story:
A bit about the artists

Hi! My name is Pippa Possible. I am a Portland-based artist. I received my BFA from the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, where I focused my practice in time-arts, and sculptural installation.

http://www.artslant.com/global/artists/show/168473-pippa-possible

http://www.saatchionline.com/pippapossible

recent exhibit: 2012 http://www.tanneryartscenter.org/ai1ec_event/art-as-experience-performance-art/?instance_id

 

My father is California-based artist, Ian Everard. 

http://www.artslant.com/global/artists/show/16847-ian-everard

http://ianeverardart.wordpress.com/

 

The Show, 'Re-generating Tradition', aka the reason for this campaign

Dad and I have been invited to participate in a group show, titled 'Re-generating Tradition', featuring multi-generational collaborations.
The show takes place in July 2013, in the Czech Republic, at Galerie Califia, in Horažďovice, about 3 hours South of Prague, by train.

http://www.galeriecalifia.net/

For this installation, Ian Everard and I will construct a ship, made of driftwood, found on the shore of my home town of Santa Cruz, California. This is a re-enactment of a ritual from my childhood, when Dad and I used to gather driftwood, kelp and scraps of litter on the beach, in order to construct "ships", which we then christened, often with my grandmother's name, and set them sail, only to witness them disintegrate into the breakers.

"This year, in boat-form, I invoke our ritual.
At the shore we gather driftwood and detritus.
Your Cornwall recall blends with mine, of Capitola.
We invoke our ritual of shibuilding, christening, casting off. S.S. Gwendolyn, for Grandmum.

Her ship surrenders to the waves.
The cycle of work and inevitable loss.

I will hang a ghost of our ritual, in a Bohemian gallery, and wish for you. Our ghosts will be projected onto her sail."


The ship will hang from the ceiling of the gallery, as if floating, with a video of us beach-combing, and building the ships, projected onto the sail.


This is a collaborative piece, though I will be responsible for transporting and installing the work. This is my first opportunity to exhibit internationally. I am very excited to make this journey, and share this campaign with you!

 

What I Need & What You Get

In order to make my exhibition happen, I need to raise at least 2800 US dollars.
    •    Travel expenses ie. planes, trains, and automobiles, hostels, etc: $2000
    •    Materials: $300
    •    Perks production: $500                                          
 
Now, for those of you who wonder what you get out of your contribution, I would like to lay it out for you:
 
The satisfaction of supporting a huge, and fun, opportunity for me to exhibit internationally. It is my first international exhibit.
 
Giving me the opportunity to use that one semester of Czech I studied in College.
 
I have mutiple tiers of donor perks, and tears of eternal gratitude! it all depends on your budget, of course.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Other Ways You Can be part of Shipbuilding / Re-generating Tradition:

I am conscious that not everyone can contribute to my exhibition expenses with money. But there are other ways to help too:
 
Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word on facebook, twitter, friendster, email, etc!
 
Please 'like' my campaign page, as it generates more buzz, and indiegogo will find more potential donors. The more this gets reposted and liked, the more they will help me reach my goal!
 
There will be a local Portland benefit. TBA!

story:
About Us...

Collaborations was born in 2012 and set out to showcase new work and new artists in an atmosphere that supports & encourages collaboration across different disciplines.

We wanted to encourage artists, performers and theatre makers to start something- to take a leap into that project that has been in their heads for the last few months, to put pen to paper or chats to tea or chords to music or print to frame and make it happen!

In the freezing cold February of 2012, as Smock Alley Theatre was building itself around us, we were starting to build a festival within. With 14 shows, 2 play readings & a tin box, Collaborations had begun.

Over 12 days, with more than 50 performances & over 80 people involved, we made a festival. Then began to work towards 2013.

Collaborations 2013 grew a little bit bigger. 16 days, 28 shows, rehearsed readings, a writers weekend workshop with John Delaney, Paul Meade & David Horan, and a Visual Arts Exhibition. With more than 90 performances & over 160 people involved, we got a little bigger.

Collaborations 2014 kept growing. With over 57 companies, including visual artists, dancers, musicians, illustrators and clowns taking part.

Last year 8 shows that started as works in development were later programmed in Tiger Dublin Fringe.

What We Need & What You Get...

Collaborations provides a platform for work that is in development. We endeavour to provide a safe environment with feedback and encouragement to make new work within the Arts. Together with Smock Alley Theatre, we are hoping to make the 2015 festival better than before but we will need your help.

We are raising €6000 to cover the costs of essentials like Printed Materials such as Programmes and Posters, Projectors, Lighting Equipment and Ladders, Additional Rehearsal Space for the Companies, Technical Support and Operators.

This will help to showcase the fledgling ideas that the collaborators have, so they can present a version of their work to see if it works for you, the audience!

Do you want invites to fabulous parties, discounted deals or your own private cinema? Are you an Arts Shark, Flash Funder or Smock Ally?

Donate today and discover which type of supporter you are...

Risks & Challenges

We are at a time when the arts is being labeled as luxury and not a necessity.

We believe in breaking down barriers to showcase work that is accessible to all, across a variety of disciplines. Our team has gathered years of collective experience in festivals, theatre, film, visual arts, design, music, marketing, and comedy as well as the technical know-how which we want to share with companies to help them find their way.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you are unable to donate today, perhaps you can help spread the word and encourage those who can share their generosity...

    • Use this link to let people know of our campaign
    • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Summary

Having studied Art History in University, learned jewellery manufacturing, and working in an Electrical Engineering firm, I find myself in a unique position to create concepts that experiment with various materials and ideas. Over the past few years, I have dedicated a large amount of my own personal funds into creating and realizing concepts for paintings and sculptural paintings, and more recently, LED lighting pieces that bring together what has been developed with my structural paintings.


With a long list of concepts for paintings unrealized, and a hope to create new prototypes for LED lamps, I hope, with your help, to finally give life to these unborn creations. You can visit my site at www.MiesMo.com for a glimpse into my own world and style.

What I Need & What You Get

An estimated requirement for funding is $5,000. The majority of funding will be used for materials. Such materials include:

Paints (oil, acrylic, latex), Canvases, Electronics, Building Materials (Basswood, Cherrywood, etc.)

As I do create high quality prints of my pieces, contributors of any amount will be entitled to 10-15% discounts for any print(s) they wish to purchase, and/or other hand-made artisan pieces that catches you attention on my site. Other perk(s) are also available.

If the goal of $5,000 is not reached, the funds that have been accumulated will be used to realize and complete as many of the concepts that can be afforded

The Impact

I have had the blessing of having several of my works, be they paintings, structural paintings, lighting fixtures, contribute to the beauty and uniquness of several friends and clients home. I do strongly believe that the creativity and wealth of experience and knowledge that I have gained in the various, and seemingly unrelated facets of life, gives me an advantage in creating novel works of art that can contribute to artistic discourse and how we think about the role of art in our lives.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute but wish to help, please spread the word to those who are interested in supporting my endeavours!

story:
Biography

Canadian artist Laura Snider (b. 1986) is a multidisciplinary performance, installation artist and sculpture, whose work focuses on memory, time, place, and materiality. She has completed her Intermediate Ballet Examination from the Royal Academy of Dance. She has completed her third year and is working towards a BA Honours from the University of Waterloo. She has exhibited her work regionally, most recently at The Artery at the University of Waterloo. She is the recipient of several bursaries, grants and awards, bursaries from the University of Waterloo, Bernice MacCallum Hillard Bursary, Stella Margaret Callfas Bursary, Fine Arts Memorial Award for studio practice, and Excellence in Sculpture. She lives and works in Waterloo, Ontario.

 Summary

I am in my Third Year at the University of Waterloo in the Fine Arts program. I have created a "White Room". The room has been filled with obsolete technology and objects and painted white. I am exploring ideas of memory, place, material.

What We Need & What You Get

To print 20 books it will cost $355.00 plus HST. I am hoping to cover the cost of printing, postage and shipping. Even if I do not reach my goal I will still make the book either at a lower quality of print or less quantity.  Any extra monies with go towards the cost of the installation its self. 

If you contribute to my project you can receive artist made prints, mini sculptures and even a book it's self!

The Impact 

Being a student money is always a challenge. By being savvy and resourceful I have been successful in creating most of my projects thus far. This is by far the most ambitious project I have encountered. By completing this project on a professional level, I will be able to move forward 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute, spread the word, get talking about art with your friends!
story_txt:
Biography



Canadian
artist Laura Snider (b. 1986) is a multidisciplinary performance, installation
artist and sculpture, whose work focuses on memory, time, place, and
materiality. She has completed her Intermediate Ballet Examination from the
Royal Academy of Dance. She has completed her third year and is working towards
a BA Honours from the University of Waterloo. She has exhibited her work
regionally, most recently at The Artery at
the University of Waterloo. She is the recipient of several bursaries, grants
and awards, bursaries from the University of Waterloo, Bernice MacCallum Hillard Bursary, Stella Margaret
Callfas Bursary, Fine Arts Memorial Award for studio practice, and Excellence in Sculpture. She
lives and works in Waterloo, Ontario. 


 SummaryI am in my Third Year at the University of Waterloo in the Fine Arts program. I have created a "White Room". The room has been filled with obsolete technology and objects and painted white. I am exploring ideas of memory, place, material.   What We Need & What You Get To print 20 books it will cost $355.00 plus HST. I am hoping to cover the cost of printing, postage and shipping. story:
Short Summary

My name is Ronny. I am a hobby photographer and motorcycle enthusiast. So I had the idea to combine these 2 favourite hobbies of mine and do something for a good cause in the process. This is how this 'hot girls on bikes' calendar came about.

At this point I am almost finished with the photo shoots. Each month of the calendar will have a different model on a different motorbike. All shoots are done on locations all over Ireland, so there's a bit of Ireland to be seen as well. All the bikes for the shoots were provided by Irish bikers free of charge . I have paid all models a modelling fee and have full copyright ownership of all images - so it's all above board.

What We Need & What You Get

Now here is where I need your help. All monies raised from the sale of this calendar should go to charity. The members of the biker community who supplied the bikes for the shoots voted for the National Council for the Blind in Ireland.

The plan is to print and sell 2000 of these calendars at a price of €10 each. I have already spent several 100 euros paying the model fees and travel expenses. The bikers who took part have supplied their bikes free of charge - now I need to get the printing financed. For this I need €2.200.

You can help in several ways. Obviously you can make a donation - however small or large - every $, €, £ or whatever your currency, helps and is much appreciated. You can just tell friends, family, or anyone else about this and ask them to help. Or you can just buy the calendar (or buy a few to sell on or give to people as presents) - see perks!

If I don't get the entire amount I will have to print less calendars, but the general idea will be the same. Please help me to make it a nice round number for charity though!

The sale of the calendar is already all but guaranteed (sale will be through a number of shops, online and a number of friends and family will sell them at work and to their friends, etc.)

The Impact

By the nature of this campaign - being a calendar - the entire donation will be available to the charity by the start of the new year. Or, if it goes really well, maybe even for Christmas!

story:
Association KROKODIL - Short History

KROKODIL started in 2009 with the first edition of its literary festival. (Btw, you probably had no way of knowing that K.R.O.K.O.D.I.L is actually an acronym. In translation from the language of the region of the Western Balkans (formerly known as Serbo-Croatian) it stands for "Literary Regional Gathering Which Alleviates Boredom and Lethargy". This was and still remains a perfect definition of our core mission - to help reconnect literary scenes of the region  ravaged by ethnic nationalism, series of brutal bloody wars that span throughout the 1990's and the violent disintegration of the former multicultural country known as Yugoslavia into petty ethnic states that sadly replaced it. Immediately after the success of our very first regional literary festival, we formed our independent and non-profit Association KROKODIL (http://www.krokodil.rs/eng/), and under the aegis KROKODIL Engaging Words we introduced a myriad of different and unique activities of engaging words (KROKODIL's Writer-in-Residence program, KROKODOKODIL festival of literature and illustration for children, annual Belgrade Debate on Europe etc.), grew bigger in both size and importance for the whole decade and recently celebrated our tenth anniversary in a big way. 

Association KROKODIL positioned itself somewhere in the middle of the road between culture and activism. this formula helped us to become one of the most credible cultural institutions not only in Serbia and the region of the Western Balkans but in Europe too. Not so long ago we were awarded with the European Communications Award for our achievements in bringing audiences back to literary events.

 

KCCL or KROKODIL's Center for Contemporary Literature

The inauguration of KROKODIL's Center for Contemporary Literature is a next logical step in our development. Recently we rented a place in the middle of Belgrade's vibrant and dynamic Savamala creative district and now we dearly need your help in order to renovate it, transform it into a literary center, acquire necessary equipment and have it all set up and ready to launch as soon as possible.

We intend to turn these premises into a friendly venue for regular events, workshops, different readings and presentations of regional, European and global writers. The doors of KROKODIL's Center for Contemporary Literature will be open to our partners, visitors and fans, friends and curious minded individuals throughout the year. This will be a great new place to come and meet your favorite authors, attend different meetings, happenings and other cultural events but also to simply hang out with your friends.  

KROKODIL's  Center for Contemporary Literature will be a non smoking, baby and pet friendly place that will provide high quality literary and cultural programs for all.

What Are You Actually Funding

We need altogether 17 500 USD in order to thoroughly transform the existing location into a cultural and literary center that would sum up different KROKODIL's activities and allow us to service our community in the best possible way.

Here is the break-down of our basic necessities:

  • renovation (walls, floors, doors and windows, painting, cleaning and other works): 6000 USD
  • new furniture (seats, tables and chairs, sofa, shelfs, lamps etc.):                                    4500 USD
  • new equipment (stage, PA system, microphones, video-projector, lights etc.):          7000 USD
  • TOTAL                                                                                                                               17500 USD

 

Why Fund KCCL

Association KROKODIL is well respected among the open minded people throughout the region of the Western Balkans  for its anti-parochial and anti-nationalistic attitudes which are actively promoted and clearly expressed through cultural, literary and activist engagament. Our regular project as well as one time events are all designed in order to foster change in the society and to transform our community into a better place for our children. We do believe into acting locally and thinking globally and we shun both inferiority and superiority complex. We trust our guts, hard working habits and a fantastic team of individuals that we gathered around the idea that the change is possible and even imminent if one truly believes in it. We will know how to make it work within the boundaries of KCCL but we do need your help in order to be able to achieve it.

With your kind contribution KROKODIL's Center for Contemporary Literature is bound to flourish and develop further. If you cannot provide financial help, other means of support are equally valuable for us. Please, help us spread the word out, share our campaign with your friends and individuals that you think could be interested in this, use social media and Indiegogo share tools in order to shout out to the world about this great initiative. And last but certainly not the least, get in touch with us and be a part of the team that knows how to do great stuff.

story:
UPDATE:  June 15, 2016

Thank You.  

We are humbled. We are grateful. We are bringing you the best little bar west of the Mississippi. Thank you for making this campaign and our project a huge success.

The Eggs Bar team


UPDATE:  June 5, 2016

We thought we'd show you what we'd been up to...

There's a rough rendering of the bar and it's going to be big...I mean REALLY BIG.  

Now this is just a drawing...just wait til Eggchair Steve gets his designs all over this facade.  Right?  

You can get a teeny taste of our progress - the team has been cranking away at our build site:

More to come!


Your Neighborhood Bar since 2004

Everyone has their favorite watering hole and we want EGGS BAR to be yours.  Your home away from home, where you can faceplant in the dust and we'll cover you with a blanket to let you sleep it off; a place where we'll make fun of you to your face, but miss you when you leave; a place where everybody knows your name...or at least what you were wearing yesterday.  

Dance on top of the bar?  Hell yeah!  Grab the mic and belt out some Karaoke?  Why not!  Set something on fire, just because you can?  Uhh...sure...well, maybe?


EGGS BAR 2016 Needs your help!

We're here to celebrate you!  But we need THREE things to make that happen:

  • Money
  • Booze
  • A bunch of crazy builders, you know, to build the thing.

The great news is that we have builders, we have a build space, we have a cheering section, we have a beer fridge, we have EVERYTHING a playa project needs to get start.   

Here's the deal:

Build Space:  $1,500
Building Materials:  $3,500
Transportation:  $1,500
Decor:  $1,000
Furniture:  $1,000
Booze:  $2,000 (minimum)
Ice & Mixers:  $500

INITIAL BUDGET:  $11,000

We've been working hard to bring the bar to you!  With our camp contribution and our RessurEGGtion fundraiser, we've raised $6,000.  We're asking your help to raise the remainder.  We're starting our campaign small - help us raise $5,000! 

The MORE money we raise, the MORE booze we can buy and the MORE drinks we can pour down your dusty throats.  That's right: more money, more booze.  



Risks?

Ask yourself...can we risk NOT having EGGS BAR?  Can we?  I think not.  But don't just take my word for it...Look at these smiling faces.  Think of how happy they are to be at EGGS BAR.  

What happens if we can't raise the money?  Well since we're already over halfway there, we're confident we can raise enough to bring the bar.  But with your help, we'll have a bar with actual booze.  And a stage.  And a sound system. And much much more!

Check out these Thank You Perks!

Eggs Bar Custom 3-color T-Shirt

Custom Name Art by Eggchair Steve (sample)

Wacky and weird Trophy handmade by Jonesy Jones (Sample)

Got a favorite perk idea?  Send it to us, maybe we'll add it!  


Other Ways You Can Help

We know...you give and give and give.  And these playa projects just keep asking for more.  If you're looking for other ways to contribute, join our group on Facebook and we'll invite you to some of our rockin' EGGS BAR Parties in the Bay Area (and Canada!).  


Where are we building the bar?

We are ecstatic to announce our new build location at The Factory 510 shared artist/maker space in San Leandro.  If you find yourself in the Bay Area and want to come help out, drop us a line!

story:
**Thank You all for getting us to our goal! We encourage everyone to continue donating, because every dollar over our goal is only going to make this event and Gallery Pixelated even better!

Thanks,

Gallery Pixelated Gang**

Who we are

Gallery Pixelated is an online gallery. Since going live in October of 2012, we have shown over 20 artists in our monthly shows and have reached out to over 4,000 viewers. Residing solely on the internet, we explore different ways of curating as well as making art in hopes of starting a conversation with the well-seasoned art viewer and the internet passerby.
 
We are a bunch of college students showing work that we are looking at, talking about things we are thinking about and exploring the world we are aiming to enter in post-graduate life.  Gallery Pixelated is our adventure.  Join us by helping us out here.

What We Plan to do at Manifest

We are all about art, and so is Columbia College Chicago. So what better way to honor this sentiment and all of the awesome artistic students at Columbia, then to create a large scale interactive art piece!

We will have a large piece of blank plywood featuring our logo. The rest will be up to the attendees of Manifest. We will have several different drawing materials for the community to express and show off their amazing talents on our art piece. 

During Manifest our awesome videographer, Rudy Lorejo, will take a time lapse video of the progress, and both an image of the final product and the video will be featured on www.gallerypixelated.com .

 

What your donation will get us

The money we raise will go to supplies and promotional materials during manifest.

This includes

  • Materials for our Interactive Art Piece, (plywood, paint markers, stencils and other drawing materials)
  • Postcards and buttons to be given out to the public
  • T-shirts for staff and team members during Manifest. 

Our $500 goal reaches our bare minimum for these materials and every dollar will go directly towards the event and Gallery Pixelated's efforts to get our name out there.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are in the Chicago area, make sure to come visit our space at Manifest Urban Arts Festival on May 17th. We will be located in the Bike lot on 8th and Wabash. We will have more details about time and all the specifics as it gets closer to the event.

If you aren't in the Chicago area, please go like us on facebook, follow us on twitter and Instagram, and subscribe to our emails to get all of the awesome updates and information about Gallery Pixelated. We are always improving, and creating new endeavors for ourself so always stay tuned!

story:
Short Summary

"Love. Not loss." These three powerful words, put together by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), have profoundly changed the way I look at my work. For the past four years, my paintings have reflected my grief about the loss and degredation of ocean species and ecosystems. But it's love that makes us human, and love that ignites our passion to want to protect the natural world.

My new artwork, funded by this campaign, will find ways to talk about my passion and love for the ocean. It will explore the incredible life forms in coastal marine environments along the west coast of North America, from Baja Mexico to British Columbia. It will focus on the interconnections between species in specific local ecosystems, and also follow the migratory paths of both grey whales and Brant geese. Both these species winter in Baja, Mexico, and then migrate to north for the summer. Both arrive at Vancouver Island, BC, in March and are greeted by locals and conservationists alike.

This campaign will fund my time for three months of research and creation of new work, from January through the end of March. I'll spend February with the whales and geese in Baja, while learning more about the marine ecosystems there that support them. I'll then return north and head to Vancouver Island to see the whales and geese when they arrive in March, which also corresponds with the Pacific herring spawn. Wherever I am, I will continue to seek out local scientists and conservationists to learn more about different species and how they are interconnected.

My hope with the new work is to inspire others to learn more about the ocean and actively protect marine ecosystems for future generations. To this end, I will be donating the use of any of the images I create to non-profit ocean conservation organizations for their advocacy and awareness work.

About me

I'm an independent visual artist and writer based in Vancouver, BC, on the west coast of Canada. My art reflects my passion about the ocean as well as my concerns about climate change, habitat loss, pollution and overfishing. With my work, I support local environmental organizations engaged in ocean advocacy. I recently completed a successful Indiegogo campaign to fund the design and printing of a calendar of my ocean paintings and am donating part of the proceeds to The Dogwood Initiative and the Georgia Strait Alliance.

What I Need & What You Get

The funding I receive will cover my regular living expenses so I can dedicate my time to research and creating new work. Because I'm ready to create a whole new series of work, an intensive period of study where I'm not working on other projects is essential.  

I'm looking to raise $6,000 to cover three months of living expenses. This is pretty bare bones but I'll make it work. I'm fortunate that my travel expenses to Baja and my accommodation there are already covered. If I raise less, I'll shrink my research time. If I raise more, I'll extend the amount of time I can keep creating and also be able to pay for guided boat excursions and snorkelling trips to see life underwater. 

In return for your support, I'm offering a range of perks from personalized thank you cards and regular email updates to original artwork. All contributors will have the option of being recognized on a new "Patrons" page on my website.

Other Ways You Can Help

Regardless of whether you're able to make a contribution at this time, I'd love your help spreading the word about my campaign. Indiegogo has easy tools to help you share on Facebook and Twitter, and then there's plain old word of mouth and a quick email with a link to this page. I appreciate every boost! Thanks in advance for your help.

Short Summary
"Love. Not loss." These three powerful words, put together by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN), have profoundly changed the way I look at my work. For the past four years, my paintings have reflected my grief about the loss and degredation of ocean species and ecosystems. But it's love that makes us human, and love that ignites our passion to want to protect the natural world.
My new artwork, funded by this campaign, will find ways to talk about my passion and love for the ocean. It will explore the incredible life forms in coastal marine environments along the west coast of North America, from Baja Mexico to British Columbia. It will focus on the interconnections between species in specific local ecosystems, and also follow the migratory paths of both grey whales and Brant geese. Both these species winter in Baja, Mexico, and then migrate to north for the summer. Both arrive at Vancouver Island, BC, in March and are greeted by locals and conservationists alike.
This campaign will fund my time for three months of research and creation of new work, from January through the end of March. I'll spend February with the whales and geese in Baja, while learning more about the marine ecosystems there that support them. I'll then return north and head to Vancouver Island to see the whales and geese when they arrive in March, which also corresponds with the Pacific herring spawn. Wherever I am, I will continue to seek out local scientists and conservationists to learn more about different species and how they are interconnected.
My hope with the new work is to inspire others to learn more about the ocean and actively protect marine ecosystems for future generations. To this end, I will be donating the use of any of the images I create to non-profit ocean conservation organizations for their advocacy and awareness work.
About me
I'm an independent visual artist and writer based in Vancouver, BC, on the west coast of Canada. My art reflects my passion about the ocean as well as my concerns about climate change, habitat loss, pollution and overfishing. With my work, I support local environmental organizations engaged in ocean advocacy. I recently completed a successful Indiegogo campaign to fund the design and printing of a calendar of my ocean paintings and am donating part of the proceeds to The Dogwood Initiative and the Georgia Strait Alliance.


What I Need & What You Get
The funding I receive will cover my regular living expenses so I can dedicate my time to research and creating new work. Because I'm ready to create a whole new series of work, an intensive period of study where I'm not working on other projects is essential.  
I'm looking to raise $6,000 to cover three months of living expenses. This is pretty bare bones but I'll make it work. I'm fortunate that my travel expenses to Baja and my accommodation there are already covered. If I raise less, I'll shrink my research time. If I raise more, I'll extend the amount of time I can keep creating and also be able to pay for guided boat excursions and snorkelling trips to see life underwater. 
In return for your support, I'm offering a range of perks from personalized thank you cards and regular email updates to original artwork. All contributors will have the option of being recognized on a new "Patrons" page on my website.


Other Ways You Can Help
Regardless of whether you're able to make a contribution at this time, I'd love your help spreading the word about my campaign. Indiegogo has easy tools to help you share on Facebook and Twitter, and then there's plain old word of mouth and a quick email with a link to this page. I appreciate every boost! Thanks in advance for your help.

story:
Tinfoil Muse

  The Pre-Order Series of Fine Art Nude Photographs Printed on Luxurious Collectible Paper or Metal media. To help Honor The beauty of the female figure.

 

First Impressions

   The female figure is arguably one of the most beautiful subjects to ever grace our universe.The project Tinfoil Muse is a look at how light and shadow create a magnificent graphic interpretation of the female figure. 

     The combination of the light and shadow captured for this project along with the print medium fuse to create an unbelievable level of high-definition that can only be experienced in person. This process results in a luxurious and long lasting print that will allow future generations to enjoy.

      The Pre-order Series will only feature 8 for the gallery of the total 17 individual looks available for order. You have 17 separate images to choose your print from. A link to the individual images can be found here.

http://brianmorrisphotography.viewbook.com/album/tinfoil-muse#1

 

 

 Why Luxury Metal Prints are Super Fine like Cameron Diaz

     I've been in the photographic industry for a long time now, most of my life in fact. When the metallic papers came out as a public option for printing, we photographers were super excited by the magical look they produced. 

      Metal prints are a hi-def look into photographic print media, The technique creates the reaction you see when looking at a hi-def television.  I remember the first time I watched hi-def t.v. and saw all those rain drops falling on a football field during a game. When slowed down how surreal the impression was. It was like time stood still and you cold reach in and grab them.

      Trying to describe these prints is very difficult, so I will share a little personal story to illustrate the impact of a metallic print.  A few years ago at the back entrance to Yosemite, I ran into Justin Timberlake and some pro snowboarders chillen' on a park bench. This was a precursor of what was about to happen in the store.

      While waiting for the bathroom, I heard the lock click and suddenly like out of a movie everything slowed down, the door opened, smoke poured out of the room, an abundance of back light created a shadowy silhouette as a tall female figure moved towards me. A wind started to blow her hair as she entered the hallway with a giant smile..... I realized Cameron Diaz was walking right at me.

   I was thinking, "Wow, I get to meet her" when suddenly out of a side door, the store manager steps in front of me. I heard the sound of screeching tires as my lil moment crashed to a halt.

   It was rather surreal and very weird, sorta like an 80's teen movie. A weird science moment. (Kelly Lebrock anyone?)  MY jaw dropped because, as a fashion photographer, I have always respected the beauty of that young lady. The experience was forever trapped in my mind. It was awesome!

    These metal prints do the same thing for me and I hope that they convey a similar feeling or pattern of thought for those creative types out there that can touch, see and feel them. An eye gouging effect!

 

 Print code                                                                      Crystaleyezed_1049.jpg

To order your print you will need to provide me with all shipping info and this print title found at the bottom right corner of the image in the image gallery.                                                                               

The Relationship Between You, Me and the Public Eye

  Funding for this series will be used for getting the series seen by the public's eye.  The series will hang in various art shows and make their appearances in the greater L.A area.  Hopefully somewhere down the road they will travel. Also a portion of your funds that goes beyond the 3000.00 needed to build the gallery will go to support the research of breast cancer. So please show our mothers, wives, sisters, daughters and female friends that we appreciate and love them .

  I want to Thank all of you for first being supportive of the arts and also for trusting me to bring you my Vision with passion.  Without value, I wouldn't want to be anything else in this world, so stay blessed and believe!

 About the Artist's Journey through Life

     My magnificent journey in art started more than 30 years ago in Northern California and has landed me in Los Angeles.  Visual aesthetics have been the driving force of who I am while I live my short existence in this lifetime.

         This Journey, has been inspired by art, fashion, design, music and an active lifestyle. I capture our world from this perspective.  My pictures are made and tuned by the magnificence of organized chaos mixed with technologies of various mediums.  Years of production practice, assisting other photographers, filming and making commercial art and visuals have paved the way for my own passion

      I see the world thru hyper-sensitive involvement.  I am on a constant search for ethical value, integrity, truth and dignity found in the knowledge collected by the greats from throughout history. I study not just how the masters use their tools, but also about their world beliefs and the system that afforded them a way of survival. Without getting political, I believe that I, as an artist, must capture our moments in time with my art.

      I lurk somewhere in the universe between black holes (shadows) and sunbursts (light) with integrity and intent to manipulate a vision with the light and shadows. I am constantly In-search of very clean / sterile environments of light or super dark and dirty cinema-graphic environments. Plus all of the varieties found in the middle.

     As a photographer, I love the subtle wrap of gradient that confirms form.  I love how the metal print and its reflective surface is elegant and compliments the fashion, yoga and dance inspired poses. These valuable and luxurious prints are a sign of our time and will be cherished for long after both the muse and I've been gone.

      I have been lucky to travel down some light and dark alleys and I have come out unscathed with a much deeper appreciation for integrity and purpose. I want you to have a piece of my journey. Made with love, integrity and truth, from my heart and soul.

 

I introduce to you Tinfoil Muse

 

By Brian Morris

Please Remember That, if this project goes over the needed funds for the gallery , I will be using a portion of the funds to help in the research of breast cancer. Not only do we respect women by embracing the beauty of the form and figure but we are telling them that it is worthy of our Honor.

campaign_city: Long Beach / Los Angeles, United States

story:
UnBox is an inspired re-imagining of the festival experience - the first and only one of its kind in India that celebrates interdisciplinary processes and innovation, and in doing so, actively forges a community of like minds to come together, create, build and share. 

How it all began

Two years ago, four creative practices (Quicksand, Codesign, BLOT and Blindboys) in India came together to make something special happen. Most conferences that we had been to had great speakers and created much inspiration, but never really got us to do much or engage with others. We knew there was another way.

We wanted to create a space where people could immerse, question, debate and make.  More importantly, we wanted it to be a space for ideas to collide with each other and give rise to new interactions and collaborations.  We wanted UnBox to become a concentrated experience of all that we seek in our daily lives, in our own practices and we called this space “Action at the Intersections.’

We have had two successful editions of the festival so far. Now entering its third year, the 2013 edition of the festival seeks to connect participants in experiential formats; in the pursuit of a rich, open & connected way of life. 

 

UnBox wants to create more ways to engage meaningfully with ourselves and the world around us.  We want to grow the festival and delve deeper, whilst staying true to our independent and pioneering spirit. 

 UnBox 2013 will take place 6-10 February 2013

Conferences

We are inviting leading practitioners from the fields of design, art, science, social innovation, technology and business to get together and act as catalysts for collaborative, inter-disciplinary conversations and action. The 2013 list is still evolving and we’ll be announcing updates soon.  

Last year we had speakers from across the globe discussing and debating topics ranging from habitat to understanding crafts to designing for communities to digital activism.

Workshops

In 2013 we want to emphasise immersive & intimate learning experiences over multiple days of the festival, tying together new learnings and previous experiences, and giving participants a chance to learn and collaborate on projects together with other participants from different backgrounds. 

Workshops that seek to bring together participants from varied backgrounds in a spirit of open collaboration will be a big focus of UnBox 2013. 

Performances and Countrywide events

Along the way we are partnering with other collectives and individuals to spread the UnBox community across India and to create magical theatre, dance and audio visual experiences that leap into the unexpected, immersing and engaging participants. 

Fellowships

The UnBox Fellowships are a core component of the festival. Inspiring projects across India will bring together young creative practitioners  from different backgrounds to work on socially relevant challenges alongside inspiring partner organizations, while pushing the “action at the intersections” in new directions. 

Help Make UnBox 2013 Possible!  

In addition to a whole heap of instant good karma and our eternal gratitude, we have curated a bunch of goodies, to show our appreciation for all your support. 

This is no ordinary swag - designed in-house and crafted with locally sourced materials, each reward was born out of things that inspire us and truly epitomizes the UnBox spirit of love for bespoke and unique objects. 

Check out the full list of rewards, look out for updates - contribute, connect, share our message and create something amazing with us!

story:
Short Summary

With the creation of Chicago Comb Co. in 2010, Tedd and John launched a new direction in comb design.  Our philosophy is to create combs that are enduring works of sculpture and design. Chicago Combs are laser-cut from solid stainless steel and hand-finished for comfortable daily use.  

Check out the amazing video the City of Chicago recently made about us, part of a series on locally made products!

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $10,000 to fund the final development and initial manufacturing costs of two new combs.  

Model No. 2 will be a full size, fine-tooth stainless steel comb.  It'll be perfect for people with longer/thicker hair, and will also provide the unique styling experience you can only get with a fine-tooth comb.

Model No. 3 is another step in our dream of creating a full line of amazing, high quality stainless steel combs.  It'll be a four inch long, multi-use comb, perfect for traveling, or as a beard/mustache comb.

Contributors will receive our acclaimed Model No. 1 comb (in stock and ready to ship), which has received praise from Art of Manliness, Cool Hunting, and others.

The Impact

Your contribution will help us to grow our company while continuing our tradition of high quality, local artisan manufacturing.  With your contribution you will receive a little piece of Chicago with our combs, while providing additional support to local manufacturers. 

You'll also receive a product which will last forever.  Chicago Combs are the antithesis of the cheap, plastic combs which are normally seen on the market. They are designed to provide a lifetime of comfortable daily use and to do so in a way that promotes great design.
