story:
HAWKMOON is a costume design driven, cross-disciplinary performance art event created through the collaboration of over 20 Bay Area artists.  Inspired by a collection of stories titled Hawk Moon by American writer Sam Shepard, the piece explores themes of gender, misogyny, PTSD, and schizophrenia through a Glam Rock lens! HAWKMOON offers magical realism in a non-linear design driven performance. 

HAWKMOON features:

  • Outlandish Costumes, Makeup & Wigs
  • Original Sound Art
  • Lighting Design
  • Paintings, Drawings, and Collage
  • Photography
  • Literature, and live writing 
  • Live performances by actors, singers, and drag artists
  • Live Rock and Roll by Bobb Saggeth the world's most fabulous Black Sabbath cover band!!


JANUARY 2016 HAWKMOON will launch with two performances at 
The Shotgun Studios in Berkeley.

Shotgun Studios 1201 University Avenue, Berkeley CA 94702 

January 16th & 17th 7pm-10pm

Open Gallery / Performance Art Installation from 7pm - 8pm

Live Band - Bobb Saggeth at 8:30pm 


Performers will be arranged in tableaux throughout the building. The installations are slow motion looping snapshots inspired by the climactic endings of six Sam Shepard stories. You’ll meet 13 peculiar characters each possessing their own dream-like qualities, but connected through a magical Glam Rock world. Using solely the visual and aural languages of design the actors are asked to intuitively play with their characters, and allow the shape of their performance to organically form and remain improvisational. Although inspired by a literary source, the performance has no scripted interactions, and narrative elements come secondary to artistic framing. The piece asks, what makes character? The performer, the designer, the text? Can you remove one and still have the others?  

In HAWKMOON  an array of multidisciplinary arts all function together as cyclical sources of inspiration, and an ongoing means of interaction between artist and audience. Character collages, costume renderings, rehearsal stills, portrait photography, notable journal entries, and excerpts from Sam Shepard’s text will be displayed to allow the audience a glimpse into the project's evolution. Additionally, copies of Shepard’s book will be available for sale. To continue the creative cycle, a local writer and painter will be present to respond to the performance with live poetry and painting. As an epilogue, a live rock n roll band will play, allowing the energy of the evening to climax, and break the spell of the tableaux with a cathartically invigorating spirit. Lastly, a cassette recorder will be placed at the exit providing an interactive element that invites whimsical commentary from the audience as they leave. 

HAWKMOON is a vision galvanized by Bay Area theatre artists motivated by a desire to challenge traditional text-based performance and the rigid structuralist style of American drama. We want to create work that transcends traditional notions of “theatre” and explodes beyond the singleness of the term. Subsequently we construct a multidisciplinary performance whose integrity can be compared against the greater terms of “ART.” This project offers a freedom to create without boundaries, to experiment in a non-autocratic culture, and to foster new connections and enhance the value of our community. 

We are a group of professional artists with knowledge, techniques, and experience. We understand the cost of presenting a performance, and through your support on this indigogo campaign we'll bring this work to life, and be able to provide proper compensation for our team. Whats really great about this campaign, is the more you donate the more our artists get paid, and the more you help sustain the evolution of art in your community! 

Your Contribution adds fuel to sustain a culturally active community in the Bay Area, and helps to keep it as a viable place in the national art scene where experimental exciting work is happening. Incorporating art and culture into the daily lives of everyone in our community has a priceless social benefit. We are so grateful to you for recognizing the value of collaborative local arts.  With the success of this event we hope to continue an ongoing cross-pollination of art making in our new communities, as well as with its audiences. And furthermore, to continue creating work in the vein and spirit of freedom through experimentation. 

Funds Raised In This Indigogo Campaign Go Directly Towards:

  • Compensation for artists 
  • Materials for Costumes, Hair & Makeup
  • Rental Costs for Sound & Light equipment 


Take a look at our budget to see how our funds are distributed!


CAN'T DONATE? 

No Sweat! There are lots of ways you can help support HAWKMOON:

  • Share this campaign on your networks!
  • Promote the event in your community
  • Donate in-kind goods!
  • Volunteer at the event!

Featuring Performances by: Rotimi Agbabiaka, Gabby Battista, El Beh, Madeline HD Brown, Hannah Birch Carl, Jamella Cross, Rami Magron, Sarah Mitchell, Sarah Moser, Lauren Spencer, Beth Wilmurt, Don Wood, and Christopher Ward White

Original Designs by: Christine Crook, Joey Postil, and Matt Stines

Live Painting and Poetry by: James Alesi, and Liz Hille 

All HAWKMOON Photography by: Lucille Lawrence
Teaser & Campaign Videos by: Matt Stines
Check out & please "LIKE" our HAWKMOON Facebook page! 
https://www.facebook.com/hawkmoonglamrock/?ref=hl
Learn more about me, Christine Crook - Costume Designer here: christinecrook.squarespace.com
Learn more about our Photographer Lucille Lawrence here: http://www.lucillelawrencephotography.com

live rock n roll band will play, allowing the energy of the evening
to climax, and break the spell of the tableaux with a cathartically
invigorating spirit. Lastly, a cassette
recorder will be placed at the exit providing an interactive element
that invites whimsical commentary from the audience as they leave. 

HAWKMOON
is a vision galvanized by Bay Area theatre artists motivated by a
desire to challenge traditional text-based performance and the rigid
structuralist style of American drama. We want to create work that
transcends traditional notions of “theatre” and explodes beyond
the singleness of the term. Subsequently we  construct a
multidisciplinary performance whose integrity can be compared against
the greater terms of “ART.”  This project offers a freedom to
create without boundaries, to experiment in a non-autocratic culture,
and to foster new connections and enhance
the value of our community. We are a group of professional
artists with knowledge, techniques, and experience.
We understand the cost of presenting a performance, and
through your support on this indigogo campaign we'll
bring this work to life, and be able to provide proper compensation
for our team.  Whats
really great about this campaign, is the more you donate the more our
artists get paid, and the more you help sustain the evolution of art
in your community! 
Your Contribution adds fuel to sustain a
culturally
active community in the Bay Area, and helps to keep it as a viable place in the
national art scene where experimental exciting work is happening. Incorporating
art and culture into the daily lives of everyone in our community has
a priceless social benefit. We are so grateful to you for recognizing the value of collaborative local arts.  With
the success of this event we hope to continue
an ongoing cross-pollination of art making in our new communities, as
well as with its audiences. And
furthermore, to continue creating work in the vein and spirit of
freedom through experimentation. Funds Raised In This Indigogo Campaign Go Directly Towards:
Compensation for artists 
Materials for Costumes, Hair & Makeup

Rental Costs for Sound & Light equipment 
Take a look at our budget to see how our funds are distributed!CAN'T DONATE? No Sweat! There are lots of ways you can help support HAWKMOON:
Share this campaign on your networks!
Promote the event in your community
Donate in-kind goods!
Volunteer at the event!



Featuring Performances by: Rotimi Agbabiaka, Gabby Battista, El Beh, Madeline HD Brown, Hannah Birch Carl, Jamella Cross, Rami Magron, Sarah Mitchell, Sarah Moser, Lauren Spencer, Beth Wilmurt, Don Wood, and Christopher Ward White
Original Designs by: Christine Crook, Joey Postil, and Matt Stines
Live Painting and Poetry by: James Alesi, and Liz Hille 
All HAWKMOON Photography by: Lucille Lawrence

Teaser & Campaign Videos by: Matt Stines
Check out & please "LIKE" our HAWKMOON Facebook page! https://www.facebook.com/hawkmoonglamrock/?ref=hl
Learn more about me, Christine Crook - Costume Designer here: christinecrook.squarespace.com

Learn more about our Photographer Lucille Lawrence here: http://www.lucillelawrencephotography.com

story:
The Collaborative Artistic Experience:

Artist. Family. Community. Culture.

 

Hi!  My name is Amira.  I am an artist.  And I hope to reveal the power of a collaborative artistic experience within a family, a community, and a culture.

I used to think making art needed to be a solitary practice; that in order to fully focus and engage with the work, I had to be alone.  However, recent collaborative drawing and painting has inspired me to explore how an artistic collaboration can affect the people involved, and the final creation.

I started inviting family members to draw and paint with me.  My mom and I made several drawings using a blind collaborative process, wherein one person begins by drawing or painting a portrait of the other, and covers the work. Then the other person draws or paints a portrait of the first person.  The process is repeated until the paper is full of marks. Finally, the piece is uncovered, and the artists cooperate to resolve visual conflicts.

In alternative collaborative works, my mom and I worked simultaneously on one canvas using photographs of various family members, and children’s books from my childhood, as reference material.  Working side by side, this collaborative experience provided opportunities to observe each other’s technique and thought process the entire time.

I also collaborated with my father, brother, sister and nieces, and found meaning and inspiration in each experience. We were vulnerable, and we supported each other with mutual respect. We faced indecision and doubt, and were provided opportunities to help each other through confusing visual challenges. Throughout the process we paused for moments of reflection, observation, and communication.  We exercised patience and trust.  We abandoned control allowing for pleasant and unexpected surprises.  And in the end, both artists were excited to see how well each other’s portraits fit together to create a resolved composition.

I used to think making art needed to be an independent practice.  But I have seen that the risk of sharing a canvas or paper with another person can foster the creation of a truly intimate and raw finished work.

These collaborations have inspired me to wonder. Who else could benefit from sharing an intimate, trusting, and open-ended creative experience?  I believe there are people within families who could communicate better, connect more deeply, and love each other more after sharing a collaborative artistic experience.  Every single person has a different mind, frame of thought, pattern of reasoning – What if we provided a safe space in which people could create art together sharing their inspirations and beliefs?   I hope to discover that in collaboration we can resolve conflict.  By sharing the experience of making art with the people in our families, in our communities, and in our cultures, we can all learn something positive, something beautiful and something profound.

 

Why do I need your help?

There are several ways your support will help me achieve my goals.  To continue exploring the artistic collaborative experience, I need:

MORE ART SUPPLIES:

I currently use high quality acrylic paint, but now need to incorporate oil paint.  Oil paint has greater luminosity and more vivid color, both elements essential in creating art that strikes the viewer, affects emotion and allows for greater personal connection.

One of my goals for this project is to create several large-scale collaborative paintings, which require custom-built stretcher bars using wood and canvas.  I will need to purchase more high quality paper for drawings and watercolors.

SPACE: I now more than ever feel a deep need to pursue familial and collaborative painting and drawing themes.  I will need to pay for a larger studio space to create larger works and store the accumulated paintings and drawings.  In addition, the larger space will accommodate multiple people working collaboratively.

TIME: Painting takes time and hard work, from researching the subject, drafting preliminary sketches, preparing the canvas, mixing all the colors, taking time to reflect, and then paint, and then reflect again.

EXHIBITION: After completing a collection of paintings and drawings, and resolving my thoughts and observations, I want to share the work with you!  My goal is to rent a large space and visually convey what I have discovered.  I want this work to literally bring people together.  I hope this show will tell this story – in collaboration, we may solve problems and find truths.  There will be one large blank canvas on which all whom attend will make a mark.  We can be a community sharing a creative moment of vulnerability, honesty and positivity.

COMMUNITY OUTREACH:  Painting and drawing with my family is just the beginning.  I hope to further the collaborative artistic experience and include members of our community and beyond.  This will eventually involve applying for grants, volunteering with other families, renting community space, hiring assistants, and marketing. 

 

Thank you,

Amira Axe

www.amiraaxe.com

story:
LITTLE PHARAOH ARTS CENTER

We've been offered an historic 6000 sq/ft building in the center of town, right in the center of Little Egypt. It will begin as an art gallery/event space and grow to become our performing arts center, complete with rotating gallery and community arts space.

Our President and Chief Executive Officer, John Clancy, spent thirty years in New York City with his wife Nancy Walsh working in and helping to create the independent theater sector. They ran venues in downtown Manhattan, presenting both new and acclaimed artists such as Leigh Silverman, Richard Maxwell and Sxip Shirey. They also produced their own work including Brian Parks’ AMERICANA ABSURDUM  (“Perhaps the best combination of playwriting and production to come out of New York downtown theater in the 90s.” Paper Magazine) and C.J. Hopkins’ HORSE COUNTRY (a brilliant (and hilarious) critique of the emptiness of American life and the meaninglessness of the popular culture that attempts to fill the void.”) Toronto Globe and Mail. They then toured their productions around the world winning six Scotsman Fringe Firsts at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe and two Best of the Fringe Awards at the Adelaide Fringe.

John was honored with an OBIE award from the Village Voice in 2006 for Sustained Excellence in Direction and was the Founding Executive Director of the League of Independent Theater and Founding Board President of the Independent Theater Fund.

Now they have returned to John’s home (technically his grandparents’ Eugene and Eleanor Powers home, but John spent summers here as a boy in the 1970s) to launch their next adventure: Little Pharaoh Enterprises, Celebrating the Art in the Heartland.  

We welcome all ideas and counsel to help us accomplish our goals. If you are a local artist or know a local artist, please contact us. If you own or operate a local business and wish to help promote the area to a new outside market, please contact us. If you are a patron of the arts either locally or anywhere else and wish to hear more about our plans or wish to support our efforts, please contact us.

And thank you for your support!

story:
What the hell?

Ummm Im an artist thats why. I need some help to print this design and get it all over the planet. Lets do this thing. This is a first run of my new Eat a D*&K design. You can be the proud owner of this t-shirt or poster. Its a great conversation starter.
The T-Shirt is printed on 100 percent cotton with a soft Dye Discharge ink. It will have that soft worn rock and roll feeling to it.
The poster is printed on heavy stock paper and measures approximately 14x14 inches.

story:
Screw Tooth:

Screw Tooth started as a vehicle for creating and exploring all original live performance, visual art, music and more, in collaboration with artists of various media, performers trained and untrained, and making a whole lot of noise.

If it's not engaging its audience in a full and total way, it's not good enough!

  • For videos, photos, press and information about the projects of the past year (live shows, music, books, and more), visit screwtooth.com or the Screw Tooth Facebook Page

Where go your $$$'s?

To keep Screw Tooth entirely dedicated to the generation of new, experimental, affordable, generous, collaborative, and wild art and performance of all kinds, and to keep it focused on the art and artists involved, it requires support via fundraising from audiences and people who believe in the mission of the company.

  • 100% of money from fundraising and from ticket sales goes into future projects and to the artists and performers involved!
  • The money raised from this campaign allows not only for the upcoming three major projects, but also is a major contributing factor in Screw Tooth's ability to continue beyond them.
  • Anything at all helps!

Here are the upcoming projects!!

These upcoming projects are larger and further-reaching than anything in Screw Tooth's exciting first year!

Here is a bit more detail about the projects themselves:

CHAINMAIL [Cotte de maille] - February/March 2015

  • The vastly different but equally brutal beautiful beastly brilliant work of visiting French artists Nils Bertho & Sam Rictus will collide as they cover, in its entirety, the open space of Buntport Theater's massive 717 Lipan St warehouse with their art.

    Additionally, events and new works will be created by local artists, musicians, performers, designers, makers, and more; all built to exist in the universe created by the joined art of Sam & Nils (CLICK HERE to see their art.)

    Painted directly onto the walls, onto large panels throughout, and exploded into the third-dimension in all different ways, the exhibition will have a three week residence in the space, with weekly events full of noise and savage fun.

MUTINY 3D - February 2015

  • A collective art book with work from 32 international artists on the theme "MUTINY".

  • Presented in red/cyan anaglyph 3D! [Comes with 3D glasses.]

  • A limited edition, hand-printed and hand-bound book.

  • Here are the artists who have contributed to the book: Dave 2000, Boris Pramatarov, Daisuke Ichiba, Dav Guedin, Kevin Beaudé, Chrysope, Chris Panatier, Nils Bertho, Sam Rictus, Daniel Cantrell, Lucas Ruggieri, Samuel Bell, Wataru Kasahara, Tetsunori Tawaraya, Jurictus, Alkbazz, crippaXXXalmqvist, Zeke Clough, Marc van Elburg, Tomahawk, Shaltmira, Mathieu Desjardins, Judex, David Paleo, Luca Villani, Cazzimir Meulemans, Marie Pierre Brunel, François de Jonge, Josh Finley, The Pit, Godmachine, Basil Kincaid

  • Co-published with Mutiny Information Cafe.

XXI [working title] - May 2015
  • Screw Tooth's most technically ambitious show to date! Making use of live video in a theatrical production in a wholly new way, this sci-fi/horror-inspired exploration embraces humanity and human connection in an otherwise meaningless world of vast and beautiful yet pointless self-feeding systems. All at once it is a lovely, bleak, horrifying, innocent, strange, and electric show.

Risks & Challenges

Risks are the reason to do any of this. Every Screw Tooth project is a risk.

  • There has not yet been a Screw Tooth project like any that have preceded, and so the necessity for discovering new solutions to the inherent challenges presented by approaching previously unexplored territory is where much of the energy come from in the processes, carrying through to audiences.
  • Through rigorous work and collaboration, Screw Tooth will continue producing engaging, generous, challenging new art for audiences.

Other Ways You Can Help

I completely understand that not everyone can donate $£¢€¥, but I hope that if you can not, you will go out and yell about Screw Tooth (or whatever your internet version of that looks like)!

  • "Share", "like", etc.
Thank you so much for your continued support of this endeavor for which I have very much love and energy!
Adam Stone, Screw Tooth Artistic Director

[music in the video is 16bit & SebastiAn]

"Share", "like", etc.

story:
The Metamorphosis of ARTs East New York

 

ARTs East New York has supported the community of East New York for the past seven years; with quality art programing, exhibitions, cultural exchange programing, and our latest large scale project [re]New Lots Vendor Market & Artist Incubator. Our founder Catherine Green a resident of East New York started the organization with the idea of providing quality art programing children in East New York. ARTs East New York's mission has grown to use art as a way to address socio-economic issues that affect East New York. Our capacity as an organization has grown and so has our impact on the community. We at ARTs East New York focus our efforts around 3 pillars; Economic Development, Health & Sustainability, and Community Life and Safety. 

We have named this campaign, "Metamorphosis" because our once small arts organization is transforming. "Phase II" as we call it, is the transitions of ARTs East New York from a small local organization into a regional leader of organizations  using art to change the socio-economic issues of a neighborhood. We see ourselves as leaders in the development of holistic health in low-income neighborhoods. Due to the success of our economic and social focused initiatives, ARTs East New York's impact and reach in the community has increases greatly. Last years our programs & Initiatives included:

[re]New Lots Vendor Market and Artist Incubator -  This year as an organization marked an exciting period of dramatic growth as we launched the [re]New Lots Vendor Market & Artist Incubator. This mobile model for neighborhood revitalization activated two vacant lots towards leveraging socially engaged artists, supporting local entrepreneurs, and building community. As a one-stop shop anchored in the arts and rooted in community, [re]New Lots created a constant interplay between the arts and entrepreneurship, resulting in a renewable cycle of creativity, trade, and social exchange. All economic and artistic activity were cultivated by a professional development support system consisting of training’s, workshops, lectures, and networking events. 




Neighborhood Beautification

Mural Mile - A mural and installation program that commissions artist from within the community and abroad to produce vibrant and community reflective public arts works in a designated corridor of East NY. 


Mi Tierra

AENY took a vacant lot in East New York and turned it into a community arts and recreation space. 

Education Programs 

YAI "Young Artist Institute"- Is our high quality art programing initiative that puts talented and impactful artist-teachers in High School, Secondary and Elementary Schools in East NY. The program includes after- school and Saturday programs. 

Apprenticeship

Our apprenticeship initiative pairs artist with High School students, who learn the the artists respective crafts, while discover themselves and their own art.


Artist Registry

Our artist registry initiatives aims to map and create directory of every artist in East NY and abroad who desires to be an active member of the art community of East NY. 

Events 
ARTsPLOSION - Our Holiday Tree Lightening  is a community celebration during the winter holiday season featuring live performances, toy giveaways, and a tree lighting ceremony.
Summer Saturdays

Summer Saturdaze & Nightz is an 8-week event series that combines a global appreciation for the arts with a focus on socio-economic issues that negatively affect the East New York community.


Installationz ( Gallery Exhibitions)

We are dedicated to providing exhibition opportunities to local and international artists that in turn expose the residents of East New York to inspiring artwork. ARTs East New York’s Installationz project mounts a wide range of visual arts showcases within the context of community building and supporting East New York’s local economy. 


Key Sponsor Of  The Sanaa Festival

This year ARTs East New York sponsored The Sanaa Music and Arts Festival. Held at [re]New Lots Vendor Market & Artist Incubator, the  festival brought 1,800 art and music lovers to [re]NewLots for a 12 Hour, 50 Artists festival in the heart of East NY. 




What We Need & What You Get

For our next phase of development we want you to become a member of ARTs East New York. Gain a membership and invest in the wholistic growth of a community. Our intention is set to raise  $100,000 so that we can develop our community the right way. 

AENY will continue the programming listed above, while adding much needed developments in programming and initiatives that address the wholistic growth of our East NY community.  

Here's What That Growth Looks Like:


[re]NewLots Phase II




Art East NY Head Quarters: Community Space & Art Gallery 





ARTs East NY University

In the Metamorphosis phase of our growth we are set to launch "ARTs East New York University". ARTs East New York University is a 6 month artist fellowship program designed to enhance an artist ability to not only produce beautiful art, but use their art as a means for social change. 


Expand The Capacity for AENY To Create Quality Art Programs




The Impact

Risks & Challenges

The impact of the this communities success is regional, national and even global. East NY is the first of 14 communities in New York City to undergo Mayor De Blasio's rezone (urban renewal plans). We believe that the the community of East NY has room for development, but not at the risk of  displacement of the existing culture, artist and residents. Art East NY has been able to get ahead of the rezoning plan, along with a number of our partners, to assure that this community does not see the same displacement that so many national and international urban communities  have suffered. This is why your membership is so important to our community. Our community is your community and we want you to stand along side us as we develop our community the right way. 

Learn More Here:

Here's What You Need to Know About the Mayor's Citywide Rezoning Plan

"Become A Member Invest In A Community"

Neighborhood Beautification
Mural
Mile - A mural and installation program that commissions artist from within the
community and abroad to produce vibrant and community reflective public arts
works in a designated corridor of East NY. 





Mi Tierra


AENY took a vacant lot in East New York and turned it into a community arts and recreation space. 




Education Programs 
YAI "Young
Artist Institute"- Is our high quality art programing initiative that puts
talented and impactful artist-teachers in High School, Secondary and Elementary
Schools in East NY. The program includes after- school and Saturday programs. 



Apprenticeship


Our
apprenticeship initiative pairs artist with High School students, who learn the
the artists respective crafts, while discover themselves and their own art.








Artist Registry


Our
artist registry initiatives aims to map and create directory of every artist in
East NY and abroad who desires to be an active member of the art community of
East NY. 






Events 

ARTsPLOSION - Our Holiday Tree Lightening  is a
community celebration during the winter holiday season featuring live
performances, toy giveaways, and a tree lighting ceremony.



Summer Saturdays

Summer
Saturdaze & Nightz is an 8-week event series that combines a
global appreciation for the arts with a focus on socio-economic issues that
negatively affect the East New York community.





Installationz ( Gallery Exhibitions)
We
are dedicated to providing exhibition opportunities to local
and international artists that in turn expose the residents of East
New York to inspiring artwork. ARTs East New York’s Installationz
project mounts a wide range of visual arts showcases within the context of
community building and supporting East New York’s local economy. 






Key Sponsor Of  The Sanaa Festival
This year ARTs East New York sponsored The Sanaa Music and Arts Festival. Held at [re]New Lots Vendor Market & Artist Incubator, the  festival brought 1,800 art and music lovers to [re]NewLots for a 12 Hour, 50 Artists festival in the heart of East NY. 









   What We Need & What You Get For our next phase of development we want you to become a member of ARTs East New York. Gain a membership and invest in the wholistic growth of a community. Our intention is set to raise  $100,000 so that we can develop our community the right way. 
AENY will continue the programming listed above, while adding much needed developments in programming and initiatives that address the wholistic growth of our East NY community.  
Here's What That Growth Looks Like:

[re]NewLots Phase II








Art East NY Head Quarters: Community Space & Art Gallery 











ARTs East NY University
 In the Metamorphosis phase of our growth we are set to launch "ARTs East New York University". ARTs East New York University is a 6 month artist fellowship program designed to enhance an artist ability to not only produce beautiful art, but use their art as a means for social change. 



Expand The Capacity for AENY To Create Quality Art Programs





The Impact
Risks & Challenges

 The impact of the this communities success is regional, national and even global. East NY is the first of 14 communities in New York City to undergo Mayor De Blasio's rezone (urban renewal plans). We believe that the the community of East NY has room for development, but not at the risk of  displacement of the existing culture, artist and residents. Art East NY has been able to get ahead of the rezoning plan, along with a number of our partners, to assure that this community does not see the same displacement that so many national and international urban communities  have suffered. This is why your membership is so important to our community. Our community is your community and we want you to stand along side us as we develop our community the right way. 
Learn More Here:
Here's What You Need to Know About the Mayor's Citywide Rezoning Plan

    "Become A Member Invest In A Community"

story:
The Breakdown

Listed below are some information about myself, the project and the significance of the work. 

  • My name is Michael Mayosky and I have been painting murals for 30 years. Painting several historic murals across the country raging from Lincoln to Route 66 ranging in all styles and sizes.
  • I was commissioned by the U.S. Army to paint at the very spot the Revolutionary War started. The Military is paying for the mural but will only reimburse the supply costs upon completion of the work. The budget to get all tools needed is out of my own funds and contributors. I have reached my maximum budget already spent (3100.00), and  we need just a few more things to be able to paint the mural to completion.  
  • This mural is a total honor for myself and my family to be involved with. I want this to go as smooth as possible and there are always hurdles to jump towards the completion of the work. I have painted over a thousand murals and know what to do and what not to do. What to get, and what is not needed. Painting this quickly and accurately is only possible with the appropriate tools just outside my current budgets. 
  • The paints I am using are extremely expensive but will be able to last at least 500 years. I want to do this mural without cutting any corners on cheaper paints. We want this to last decades upon decades.
  • This mural is depicting the scene that took place during the Battle of Brooklyn which started on July 4th, 1776. I am creating the work at the very spot it took place. To read up on the fascinating history of Fort Hamilton please start with this link, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Hamilton
  • Within the restrictions of the contract for the mural, I am not allowed to paint any side projects. This would be the normal procedure for me to raise more money for another project if budgets fall short. This is not an option for getting more supplies for this mural.
  • The real complicated part of this hurdle is that I recently lost my entire studio and personal tools due to a fire last summer. It has been very difficult to recover from the loss due to the fact all my tools and supplies were destroyed.  I have built up some, but I do need help at this point.

Cold Weather Equipment Needed

The purpose of the crowd funding campaign:

  • Scaffolding. The wall is 12 feet high and under a larger awning. We will need to safely reach as far as we can go to get all surfaces clean and painted.  
  • Tarps and plastic. Creating a enclosed area to keep warm through the process will be outside my personal budget. I have already gotten the paint, several pieces of wood to build the structure and attached the tarps.
  • Rollers, brushes, spray tips, and other general items.
  • I have already purchased the paint and several other things. There is no specific goal so much as I just need everything I can get to help with the costs of the mural. The target I put is the absolute most I would need realistically. 
  • The project has already started. I have cleaned and scrapped sections of the wall and the time to start priming and painting is coming within days. 

The Army is reimbursing us with the material costs when the project is completed. Some of the contributors, (if they choose to) will get the funds back. This will be arranged through a separate contract outside of Indigogo.  Please write me at michaeljmayosky@gmail.com for more information. 

 

The Impact

Artists need patron and sponsors sometimes:

  • In this particular project, the amount of funding needed to paint this mural is greater than I can cover at once. I had lost all my tools earlier this year in a fire and I am still am recovering. However, even building back from devastation. you still need to create and work. This mural will be able to build my studio back in time but the tools still need to be immediately available. I unfortunately need help to replace these items to continue in my work.
  • Prints will be made of the is work and the people who help out will have the first prints made. Each print will be signed and numbered by myself and will surely be a great piece of history to share with your friends and family.
  • The history of this base goes all the way back to the first organized military action by the colonists in 1776.  Think of the thousands of soldiers who passed through this base on their way to the world stage is fascinating, from the Revolutionary, the Civil, and to modern engagements. In all the murals I have had the honor to paint, this one by far takes the cake in uniqueness and importance.  I am honored beyond words.

Challenges

Painting in the cold is easy but only with the right tools.

  • We have been negotiating this mural for several months and the only window the Army could provide was during the winter.
  • Panting in the cold is not impossible nor is it uncommon. There are several ways to paint in all weather conditions. However, the lower the temperature, the more equipment is needed. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share the link with whoever you feel may like being a part of this project.
  • Let me know if you have any suggestions or equipment I can borrow. Every little bit can help!
  • If you would like a detailed list of specific equipment and prices, please feel free to write me at my email. If you would like to donate equipment rather than money, I am more than agreeable. 

Thank you for your time and consideration. With just the right amount of help, this mural will be a great addition to the already historic and fascinating story of Fort Hamilton.

Panting in the cold is not impossible nor is it uncommon. There are several ways to paint in all weather conditions. However, the lower the temperature, the more equipment is needed. 



Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Share the link with whoever you feel may like being a part of this project.
Let me know if you have any suggestions or equipment I can borrow. Every little bit can help!
If you would like a detailed list of specific equipment and prices, please feel free to write me at my email. If you would like to donate equipment rather than money, I am more than agreeable. 

Thank you for your time and consideration. With just the right amount of help, this mural will be a great addition to the already historic and fascinating story of Fort Hamilton.

story:
Short Summary

This Campaign is designed to fund the launch of Save the Gingers Book. Specifically, all money received from backers will go towards printing and distribution of Save the Gingers Book. As of the launch of this campaign, the book is 100% complete, only needing extra funding for help with printing and distribution. Over 40 Natural Redheads were professionally photographed by Beau Pollock for the main layout of the book, and over 60 Gingers sent in "selfies" for the collage pages! The book looks beautiful!  

What We Need & What You Get

We need money to print this beautiful book and to market it to distributors. Your money goes directly to getting this book printed and into stores! 

    The Impact

    “SAVE THE GINGERS” is a fine arts compilation of natural redheads (aka Gingers) in a coffee table book-type format. It aims to promote Gingers as possessors of a unique and beautiful variation of natural human hair color, not only to be praised for its beauty, but celebrated for its relative rareness. We know how kids can tease and bully others with any unique traits or features, and perhaps the mere publication and distribution of this book will change that, not only for the Ginger children, but for all children and adults with unique hair and/or skin types. The title is a play on the urban legend that natural red hair is a recessive gene and is becoming extinct. The philanthropic aspect of this publication and related social media outlets is simply to bring together beautiful Gingers from around the world, rejoice in their individuality, proudly promote their heritage and possibly encourage further natural genetic replication. 

    We anticipate an initial run of 3,000 copies and have set up a distribution plan with Penguin (Random House Publishing). We also plan to promote the book in markets targeting younger demographics, such as Urban Outfitters, Kitson, Target Stores and many more.


    Risks & Challenges

    The risks have been thoroughly assessed and with the experience of previous endeavors we feel this project will launch and conclude successfully. The only potential setbacks could come with technical aspects such as backers payments not going through. When this campaign is successful, we will do everything possible to make sure the book is published in Summer 2014 and distributed accurately.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Go to for more info, to follow along and to help spread the word!

    https://www.facebook.com/savethegingersbook

story:
HOARD specimens on welded stands

Backstory

In April 2013 I undertook an elaborate installation project called HOARD. It took place in Eastworks, suite #140, in Easthampton, MA as part of the inaugural REACH Fest, a multi-city exhibition of 30+ contemporary practitioners. HOARD was a month-long site-specific installation and performance in which I went to work in the space each day and physically sawed, sliced, excavated and archived chunks from a large mountain I had previously constructed out of a conglomerate of synthetic materials.  The quarried pieces that once made up the peaks, crust and core of the six-foot high mountain, now serve on their own as a body of work. Tagged, dated, numbered and removed from their source, they act as small cross sections of our material culture and souvenirs of a labor-intensive process.

HOARD catalog photos by Jeff Derose- One Match Films

HOARD

the AUCTION

Contributors will help fund the second phase of HOARD and the culmination of the project.  During HOARD I extracted 200 specimens from the mountain sculpture and 250 specimen bags of debris from the process.  This June I will auction off 170 of these specimens through a silent auction over the course of a new month long gallery show. Specimen bags will be on sale throughout. The show will culminate with a spectacular live auction event in which a professional auctioneer will auction off the remaining 30 and most highly prized specimens.

Professional Auctioneer?

 Yes! I mean basically.... Seth Lepore, local Easthampton theater aritst will perform as the auctioneer during the event. It's sure to be quite the show!

Where it's all Happening

HOARD the Auction will take place at MAP in the Eastworks Building in Easthampton, MA. The Mill Arts Project (MAP), a collaboration between Easthampton City Arts+ and Eastworks, that offers a gallery space and to incubate new curatorial voices in a community context. While curators bring a vision and dedication, ECA+ and Eastworks assist with space and offer an intensive educational curatorial and organizational guide as well as assistance in project direction.

The location of the MAP space is kitty corner to the original HOARD space, which was an empty commercial space. Showing in unconventional spaces further blurs the line between art and reality in a way that coincides with my artistic values, which include making work that is accessible to the general public. The often jam-packed benches of the Registry of Motor Vehicles, located next door, supplied a steady flow of atypical art viewers.

Save the Dates!

  • Art show June 9th - June 28th

  • Opening Celebration,  June 14th, 5-8pm during Eathampton's Art Walk and after Cottage Street Cultural Chaos! Come place your initial bids on silent auction items!

  • Live Auction & Closing Party, June 28th, 6-9pm, Live Auction at 7:30pm

Our Goal

We are looking to raise $3250

Your donations will help cover the basic costs of undertaking the project:

  • $550 for materials such as steel for welding specimen stands, shelving for the display of specimens in the gallery and hardware
  • $900 for professional services such as welding assistance, hiring a professional photographer to document the specimens and hiring the professional auctioneer performer
  • $750 for promotional material such as posters, postcards and signage
  • $1050 for the production of 25 beautifully designed, 100 page, limited edition catalog documenting all 200 HOARD specimens

Donate and Get Specimen Bags as PERKS!

Perks!

When you donate, you will receive awesome HOARD perks at different levels!

  • Your name printed on the donor list which will be on view in the gallery
  •  HOARD collector postcards
  • authentic HOARD specimen bags from the original performance
  •  limited edition HOARD posters
  • your own limited edition copy of the HOARD catalog
  • One extra special "Trump Bid Paddle" that will allow the lucky owner to automatically outbid anyone for one specimen of their choosing during the live auction.

Why Donate?

  • To support accessible and affordable art experiences for all!
  • To support the creation of a community space for further contemplation on how and why we as people attribute value to time, labor and our material surroundings.
  • To support the artist in the creation of her final show in the Pioneer Valley before pursuing her MFA at the University of Michigan.
  • To secure some awesome HOARD perks!

About the Artist

Carolyn Clayton is the artist behind HOARD. Clayton received her BFA in 2009 from Carnegie Mellon University with a focus in sculpture, installation and site-specific work.  The sculptural systems that she creates are often activated by her own participation in labor-driven tasks, as a means to produce objects that are partially informed by chance. By making this part of her creative process public and inviting participation, Clayton examines how people attribute value to time, labor and our material surroundings. Clayton has shown in a variety of traditional and non-traditional venues in Western Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and New York.  She will begin her graduate studies this fall at the University of Michigan, Penny W. Stamps School of Art and Design, in pursuit of her MFA.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Volunteer your time in the studio
  • Volunteer to gallery sit at MAP during the month of June
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and spread the word!

story:
The Fall 2016 Program will leave NYC and drive south to Miami in 4 weeks. The program will stop in different cities (listed below) to create public art installations and murals, and stop at different National Parks to create small works on paper. The culmination of the program will be during Art Basel week in Miami where Dripped On The Road will have an open studios event to invite the public to interact with the RV, and experience the trip through photography, mural installations and an exhibition of the work created.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Your funding will give us an opportunity to help create a new and exciting platform that will positively impact, engage, and stimulate artists and creative communities alike.

 

By working with us, you will:

  • Support four artists during the month-long residency.
  • Provide 9 communities with murals in:  New York, NY, Bethlehem, PA, Washington D.C., Durham, NC, Atlanta, GA, Charleston, SC, Savannah, GA, Orlando, FL, and Miami FL.
  • Provide 3 creative communities with an artist talk with artists from our program.  
  • Provide a small stipend for each artist.
  • Enable the purchase of materials for the artists.
  • WE NEED PAINT!!!!

 

 

The Impact

Donations like yours will help artists thrive in this economy as well as bolster the careers of deserving and talented individuals:

  • Our program is unique and the first of its kind in America.
  • The magnitude of what we will be able to achieve will be immense and life changing, not only for the artists but for the communities participating as well. 

  • Artists selected for this and future programs will see America from ground level, up close and personal.

  • Our crew will work with communities to bring the best art work to their space. 

 

LOCATIONS


New York, NY
Mural with PBR
Launch Party at TBD
​

Allentown/Bethlehem, PA​
Mural with Lehigh University
Artist Talk with ArtsQuest
 

Washington D.C
Artist talk with Co-op Space


NATIONAL FOREST
George Washington and Jefferson National Park, VA ​
 

Durham, NC​
Mural Painting and Artist Talk with SPECTRE Arts
Mural Painting with FineBack Brewery
 

NATIONAL FOREST
Cherokee National Forest, NC​
 

Atlanta, GA​
Mural Painting with PBR
 

NATIONAL FOREST
Francis Marion National Forest, SC​

Charleston, SC
Mural Painting with PBR​

Savannah, GA​
Thanks giving!
Mural painting with Woody's Skatepark

Orlando, FL
Radio Show With Redefine Gallery Radio
Mural painting with -  MILLS50

Miami, FL
Final Exhibition with FU Gallery
Mural painting with PBR

​

 

Risks & Challenges

While our trip is scheduled and planned out, there are a few challenges that we may face on the road. Mainly, RAIN!

  • We may not be able to paint all of the murals on the way depending on the weather at the location. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Hey, it's all good if you cannot contribute. Here are a few other ways to help!:

  • Word of Mouth.
  • Please SHARE SHARE SHARE our campaign through facebook, instagram, twitter, etc.


PERKS

The culmination of the program will be during Art Basel week in Miami where Dripped On The Road will have an open studios event to invite the public to interact with the RV, and experience the trip through photography, mural installations and an exhibition of the work created.
 

 
What We Need & What You Get
Your funding will give us an opportunity to help create a new and exciting platform that will positively impact, engage, and stimulate artists and creative communities alike.
 
By working with us, you will:

Support four artists during the month-long residency.
Provide 9 communities with murals in:  New York, NY, Bethlehem, PA, Washington D.C., Durham, NC, Atlanta, GA, Charleston, SC, Savannah, GA, Orlando, FL, and Miami FL.
Provide 3 creative communities with an artist talk with artists from our program.  
Provide a small stipend for each artist.
Enable the purchase of materials for the artists.
WE NEED PAINT!!!!

 

 
The Impact
Donations like yours will help artists thrive in this economy as well as bolster the careers of deserving and talented individuals:

Our program is unique and the first of its kind in America.
The magnitude of what we will be able to achieve will be immense and life changing, not only for the artists but for the communities participating as well. 
Artists selected for this and future programs will see America from ground level, up close and personal.
Our crew will work with communities to bring the best art work to their space. 


 
LOCATIONS
New York, NYMural with PBRLaunch Party at TBD​
Allentown/Bethlehem, PA​Mural with Lehigh UniversityArtist Talk with ArtsQuest 
Washington D.CArtist talk with Co-op Space
NATIONAL FORESTGeorge Washington and Jefferson National Park, VA ​ 
Durham, NC​Mural Painting and Artist Talk with SPECTRE ArtsMural Painting with FineBack Brewery 
NATIONAL FORESTCherokee National Forest, NC​ 
Atlanta, GA​Mural Painting with PBR 
NATIONAL FORESTFrancis Marion National Forest, SC​
Charleston, SCMural Painting with PBR​
Savannah, GA​Thanks giving!Mural painting with Woody's Skatepark
Orlando, FLRadio Show With Redefine Gallery RadioMural painting with -  MILLS50
Miami, FLFinal Exhibition with FU GalleryMural painting with PBR
​
 
Risks & Challenges
While our trip is scheduled and planned out, there are a few challenges that we may face on the road. Mainly, RAIN!
We may not be able to paint all of the murals on the way depending on the weather at the location. 

 
Other Ways You Can Help
Hey, it's all good if you cannot contribute. Here are a few other ways to help!:

Word of Mouth.
Please SHARE SHARE SHARE our campaign through facebook, instagram, twitter, etc.


PERKS

story:
The live campaign is here:

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-metamer-...

I've always wanted to create a publication that was also art, a way to communicate ideas with images and text and in the form of the thing itself. I imagined subscribers getting a package in the mail every few months, and opening it like a gift. I wanted it to be art that you could hold and touch and move.

So, I decided to publish editions of artist's books. I called my project The Metamer Quarterly, picked the equinoxes and solstices for shipping dates, and started selling subscriptions in 2016. Issue #3, "The Book of Love," will ship in June.

You could describe an artist's book as a book that is an art object. It borrows from the attributes of books – covers, hinges, pages, text – but also expands the idea of what a book can be. Artists' books don't reproduce art or images – they are the art. The subject is often reflected in how an artist's book is made, and what it is made of, as well as in text and image. 

This format gives me both license, and some challenging boundaries. Each issue strikes a balance between originality and the need for reproduction. I plan to continue to use manual forms of reproduction as much as possible, like screenprinting and letterpress, and to always include elements that are drawn, collaged, handmade, and unique to each copy in the edition. This project is analog; its design and purpose are about physicality, objects, feel, and weight. It is art you can hold in your hands.

The first issue, “Metamerism”, came out in December of 2016: an accordion book made with heavyweight drawing paper, gel transfers, paint, rubber stamps, and containing a real glass prism. The second issue, “Maps and Diagrams”, shipped in March. It is covered in a durable bookcloth used for library editions. Inside, a folder with a star-shaped opening holds soccer coaching diagrams, an airport map turned poem, the night sky in gold leaf, and maps of childhood. I had five collaborators on this issue, which was a real joy.

Why Do You Need Funding?

I am looking to make some things happen that require more time and money. I want to explore ways to make "The Sea" feel like the sea, with materials and shapes that will evoke the sound and feel of the ocean. One of the later issues, “The Cabin and the Stone House”, about two houses that are part of my family's history, will be richer with more research, and that requires more time. I want to continue working with contributors and collaborators, and that takes time as well. I want to hand-bind “The Book of Love”, and use processes like screenprinting and letterpress for the images; taking additional classes in these areas will hone and develop my skills, allowing me to create even more interesting objects. A weekend class usually costs around $200; a week-long class is usually around $700. Attending classes at The North Bennet Street School in Boston, The Center for Book Arts in NYC, and the Western New York Book Arts Center in Buffalo, would also provide networking opportunities, for me and the Quarterly.

Funding at the set goal will allow me to focus primarily on this project for the next six months, and to spend significant time on its promotion as well as production. A stretch goal, funding beyond that level, would allow me to focus mainly on this project for the full eight issues, into 2018.

Any level of funding will expand my material and production options. Adding and developing expertise in book arts related skills gives me more ways to raise additional revenue to support the project, whether by passing those skills along, or using them in more commercial graphic design projects (logos, banners, posters), illustration (greeting cards, maps), decorative boxes, and handmade greeting cards. I am committed to producing two years of the Quarterly, and now have subscribers for all eight issues. While I think that additional funding will have a significant positive impact on The Metamer Quarterly, production is not dependent on it.

What Do I Get In Return?

At every level, you will receive original art related to The Metamer Quarterly. Perks include framable versions of art from the first two issues – a star map with gold leaf stars, and a color wheel in the medium of your choice.The higher levels include one or more issues of TMQ.

You will also get public thanks for your support  - everyone who contributes will be listed on a special Thank You page on The Metamer Quarterly website/blog. I also plan to include the names of all the IndieGoGo supporters in Issue #3, "The Book of Love."

How Else Can I Help?

Spread the word! Please share this campaign with any friend or colleague who might be interested in the project. Feel free to share the link on social media, and please contact me if you'd like some art cards to hand out.

I consider it a help too if you are supporting the arts in any way, in any place. I'm very serious! I am an artist in part because my family had their friends' art on the walls, and took us to museums and live music events and dance performances. We need the arts, and all artists need audiences – go to a show, to a museum, to exhibitions at local galleries or at the library in town. Buy more art if you can!

By The Way, What Is A Metamer?

A metamer is a color that appears, to a particular observer, to be identical to another color in some lighting situations, but not in others. That shift from match to mis-match indicates a difference in chemical make-up and spectral reflectance – the colors' light signatures – and is called metamerism. Metamers only exists in relationship to each other, and depend on who is looking and under what conditions. I like that as a metaphor. You can't be a metamer by yourself.

Metamerism is something we experience visually all the time. It is the reason that a paint chip from the hardware store can match the living room wall at night but is glaringly off in daylight. It is the socks that matched when you put them on this morning, but didn't later at the office. All colors shift depending on light and juxtaposition; metamers perform a little dance with one another, joining and separating, meeting and diverging.

And, Who Are You Again?

My name is Lara Scott, and I am an artist currently living in Central New York -- south of Utica, north of Binghamton. I grew up in Stamford, CT, and got a BA in Art at Yale University, focusing on painting and printmaking. After college, I lived in DC, and drifted in the direction of art history for awhile. Then I drifted out to California. When I realized that no matter where I drifted, I was always making art, I decided to move in a more definite direction. I returned to the east coast, and got my MFA at the University of Pennsylvania. After that, I taught studio art at two small colleges, one near St Louis, MO, and the other in VA, for over seven years. Most recently, I worked in the R&D Lab at Golden Artist Colors, also for about seven years. I am now working primarily as freelance graphic designer and illustrator, something I've done off and on for the last twenty plus years.

I work primarily in collage, oil paint, and video. 

When I was young, my family had a good friend who owned a gallery in NYC. She encouraged my artistic endeavors, in the same general way that the rest of my family did. She helped me get my first job out of college, as a research assistant at the Smithsonian's American Art Museum. I didn't see her as often as I got older, but I remember very clearly one rainy summer day when I stopped by to pay my respects, and to talk a little. “You left the museum, you left California – what are you going to do now?” she asked. “I'm getting my MFA,” I replied. “I'm going to be an artist.” She looked at me a moment, this woman who worked with artists for a living for forty years, and said, “That's a very hard life, you know. Are you sure?” I smiled. “Yes, I am.”

story:
DocNow 2016

DocNow is an interdisciplinary documentary artists’ festival featuring work from the 2016 graduating class of Ryerson University’s one-of-a-kind Documentary Media Master of Fine Arts program. This multi-arts festival pushes the boundaries of documentary, showcasing twenty evocative works by a diverse group of storytellers through installation, performance, film and exhibition. Now in its eighth year, DocNow 2016 is one of Canada’s most innovative documentary festivals created by the next generation of documentary makers.

All exhibitions and film screenings are free and open to the public.  

YOU CAN CHECK OUT PICTURES OF OUR PERKS HERE!

NOTE: If you wish to purchase any perks without shipping, please email lynne.fox@ryerson.ca with "Perk Purchase" in the subject line.

Why it's important:

DocNow appeals to a diverse and expansive audience across Toronto and beyond. This year’s festival pushes the boundaries of documentary by presenting the work of international artists using new technologies, community partnerships, and artistic innovation to tell unheard narratives from across the globe.

A sample of what will be shown at DocNow 2016:

  • An investigation into the impact of human rights violations in Kashmir
  • The challenges and tribulations of immigration for a modern Iranian-Canadian family
  • Intergenerational conversation around cultural traditions on the Sudanese-Canadian community
  • The significance of music within urban development 
  • The history of a little known flight that uprooted a group of Vietnamese children from Saigon
  • A sensory immersive installation that explores the concept of ‘flow’ in sports
  • A project that uses 360-degree camera to observe a refugee family seeking sanctuary in a Vancouver-area church

Our goal is to showcase and support the hard work of all our graduating artists by making an excellent arts festival in Toronto. Your donation will help make this a reality!

What We Need

With a large and diverse group of 20 artists, we are asking for your donation in order to fulfill the creative explorations of this year's artists. Money raised will go toward paying for: 

  • Gallery spaces for 12 exhibitions 
  • Marketing materials (print and media)
  • Installation material costs and fees
  • Printing and framing costs
  • Sound mixing and colour correction for films
  • Opening and closing night reception

The Impact

The student artists participating in DocNow 2016 want to ensure the highest caliber of artistry and professionalism in the festival. The artists represent not only themselves as emerging documentarians, but also the subjects who generously shared their stories with us.

Risks & Challenges

With its ambitious scope, including many artistic mediums and modes of presentation, DocNow's ability to support each artist's work properly is difficult. With budget cuts across the board, rising costs of materials and high prices for gallery rental in Toronto, collective projects such as DocNow 2016 need alternative support from friends, families and local businesses.

  • We are working hard as a collective to come up with new funding ideas and outreach opportunities to partner with community groups. 
  • We are looking for professional relationships that will not only support current work, but will also kick start our transition from students to professional artists. 
  • We want to leave the next Master of Fine Arts in Documentary Media class with a wealth of successful practices and partnerships.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Volunteers are needed to help with installations, documentation of the work and opening and closing nights! If you have any expertise in these areas let us know. If you just want to help out that is AMAZING!
  • Share our campaign with your own contacts or on social media.
  • Do you consider yourself a chef, a cook or a maker of yummy beverages? Food and drink donations are always appreciated.

If you're interested in becoming a major sponsor of this event or making an in-kind donation, please contact alexandra.simpson@ryerson.ca.

We look forward to your continued support in helping us make the DocNow 2016 Festival a success!

Follow our progress via our social media platforms on Twitter and Facebook (links below). Our website will give you further information about the festival and will be updated in the coming months...watch this space:  www.docnow.ca 

YOU CAN CHECK OUT PICTURES OF OUR PERKS HERE!

Participating Artists

Alyssa Bistonath
Elyse Bouvier
Anureet Caur
Mikaela Colville
Lynne Fox
Martin Franchi
Shounak Ganguly
Frances Juriansz
Tamar Mankassarian
Shivanya Mulekar
Ebti Nabag
Stephanie Power
Angie Ready
Gray Richards
Alexandra Simpson
Philip Skoczkowski
Sophie Sabet
Cyrus Sundar Singh
Golzar Taravati
Mark Tremblay

Thank you to our contributors

Blue Ice Group

Office of the President, Ryerson University

Office of the Provost, Ryerson University

Yeates School of Graduate Studies, Ryerson University

Documentary Media Program, Ryerson University

School of Image Arts, Ryerson University

Faculty of Communication, Art and Design (FCAD), Ryerson University

Ryerson Students' Union (RSU)

Ryerson Artspace at the Gladstone

Ryerson Image Centre (RIC)

Stephen Bulger Gallery

story:
Namaste, my name is Nancy Walter, and I am a printmaker, mixed media and book artist based in Encinitas, California. My campaign is to help support my (artist funded) Artist in Residence with Green Olive Arts in Morocco, which runs from January 30–March 10, 2016.

The Why

Many girls are underserved in Morocco and have no access to art in school. I will be spending time with a few neighborhood girls, teaching art and introducing them to simple techniques, as well as researching future teaching opportunities with a girls empowerment project in Marrakesh. 

The time in residency is also for research, exploration and collecting patterns, images, and traditional techniques. These components will inform the artwork and books that I create, and workshops that I teach, both while away and throughout 2016. My goal is to assist others in finding their own creative voice by using these tools as a vehicle.

This trip is about stretching myself as an artist and a person, and paying it forward.

Abstract painter, Bassmi Ibrahim said in an interview, "it is the responsibility of every serious artist to create new beauty in his or her lifetime. Beauty as yet unseen, and unique to the artist." And I believe this is a step in that direction — even if it is a lofty goal!

The What

At Green Olive Arts’ CONVERGENCE Artist Residency, I will explore the places where tradition and art come together. Ten artists from around the world will engage with local experts, immersing our selves in cultural and artistic experiences that will not only add to our set of skills, but also expand our minds and spirits. The shared experience will make this a richer, more interesting time.

Our immersion will take us through the cities of Tetouan, Chefchouan and Marrakech. Most of my time will be spent exploring and creating art in Tetouan, with five days in Marrakech for the opening ceremonies and exhibitions of the 6th Marrakech Biennale (a huge art event).


The How

My attraction to this place runs deep. Aside from the beauty of the crafts and architecture, there’s the culture and its people... some of the most generous people I’ve ever met. To say I love Morocco is an understatement—the chance to go again and use my time there creatively is intoxicating.

With your help! Every well wish, kind thought and monetary gift is appreciated. Whether or not you’re able to contribute financially, I’d love to stay in contact with you regarding future artwork, workshops and other happenings. Feel free to contact me directly or “like” me on Facebook (I’ll be posting updates before, during and after my travels). Art is all about connection and that’s what I hope my work has done for you!

The opportunity to work with a group of artists in one of my favorite places is truly an honor. Words simply cannot express how humbled and excited I am to be taking this journey. I want to thank you with my whole heart for listening to my story and for your support.



Where the money will go

Airfare (paid)
Residency: $2900 (convergence) + $750 (additional time)
Art Supplies: $400 (to be donated to the neighborhood children)
Additional baggage (art supplies): $125
Travel Insurance: $400
Inoculations: $100
Additional travel/meals costs: $325

Namaste,
Nancy

I will be spending time with a few neighborhood girls, teaching art and introducing them to simple techniques, as well as researching future teaching opportunities with a girls empowerment project in Marrakesh. The time in residency is also for research, exploration and collecting patterns, images, and traditional techniques. These components will inform the artwork and books that I create, and workshops that I teach, both while away and throughout 2016. My goal is to assist others in finding their own creative voice by using these tools as a vehicle.This trip is about stretching myself as an artist and a person, and paying it forward.Abstract painter, Bassmi Ibrahim said in an interview, "it is the responsibility of every serious artist to create new beauty in his or her lifetime. Beauty as yet unseen, and unique to the artist." And I believe this is a step in that direction — even if it is a lofty goal!
The What
At Green Olive Arts’ CONVERGENCE Artist Residency, I will
explore the places where tradition and art come together. Ten artists
from around the world will engage with local experts, immersing our selves in
cultural and artistic experiences that will not only add to our set of skills, but
also expand our minds and spirits. The shared experience will make this a
richer, more interesting time. 
Our immersion will take us through the cities of Tetouan,
Chefchouan and Marrakech. Most of my time will be spent exploring and creating
art in Tetouan, with five days in Marrakech for the opening ceremonies and
exhibitions of the 6th Marrakech Biennale (a huge art event).


The HowMy attraction to this place runs deep. Aside from the beauty of the crafts and architecture, there’s the culture and its people... some of the most generous people I’ve ever met. To say I love Morocco is an understatement—the chance to go again and use my time there creatively is intoxicating.With your help! Every well wish, kind thought and monetary
gift is appreciated. Whether or not you’re able to contribute financially, I’d
love to stay in contact with you regarding future artwork, workshops and other
happenings. Feel free to contact me directly or “like” me on Facebook (I’ll be
posting updates before, during and after my travels). Art is all about
connection and that’s what I hope my work has done for you!
The opportunity to work with a group of artists in one of my favorite places is truly an honor. Words simply
cannot express how humbled and excited I am to be taking this journey. I want
to thank you with my whole heart for listening to my story and for your support.
Where the money will goAirfare (paid)Residency: $2900 (convergence) + $750 (additional time)Art Supplies: $400 (to be donated to the neighborhood children)Additional baggage (art supplies): $125Travel Insurance: $400Inoculations: $100Additional travel/meals costs: $325
Namaste,Nancy

story:
What's a Blue Dress Cup?

Blue Dress Cup is an annual competition to determine the Best Artist in Milwaukee. At Blue Dress Park (corner of Reservoir and Holton) we pit a carefully-chosen group of competitors against one another in a series of Olympic-style games that measure qualities that are essential to a Best Artist. Last year, we had a 2m dash (where the last to cross the finish line was declared the winner), a heated basketball game (where score was not kept, but rather contestants proved their individuality through personal flair and style), and a social networking circle.

Adam Carr Hosted the event and we had a number of speakers and gust judges including Alderman Nik Kovac, John Riepnhoff, Cynthia Henry, Anna-Marie Opgennorth, and Xav Leplae.

This year we're hoping we're hoping to make Blue Dress Cup bigger and best-er by designing even more exciting games, inviting even more special guest speakers, and creating a trophy worthy of the Best Artist in Milwaukee. You can help us achieve our goal, and we have some pretty rad prizes to offer contributors.


What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise $2500 that we can use to make this event as awesome as possible. Funds raised will go to . . .

    • A shiny new trophy that we design and fabricate ourselves!
    • Bigger and better games . . . think American Gladiator, crossed with a beauty pageant, crossed with a 90's Nickelodeon game show. 
    • Designing and printing our new Contestant Application. We got to get a lot of those out there, to make sure we get quality contestants!
    • Fancy guest judges and speakers who like to get paid for their time.
    • Graphic designers for our promotional materials. They don't work cheap!

    We haven't stopped thinking since last year, and we have developed some amazing prizes for contributors to the project . . .

    Introducing the Blue Dress Cup Trading Card Game (BDCTCG)! A series of 40 collectable cards produced by local artists Oliver Sydello and Brad Fiore, in collaboration with the Friends of Blue Dress Park. Each card features a person, place, or thing related to last year's event. So many of your favorite Milwaukee cultural producers are there, including Paul Druecke, John Riepenhoff, Sara Daleiden, Anna Marie Opgennorth, and more! You can collect them all, or trade with your friends.


    Why a Blue Dress Cup?

    Last year, we succeeded in gathering artists, curators, public servants, and business owners from all over the city to take part in our event. The day proved to be a great opportunity to connect with all kinds of cultural enthusiasts. But aside from that, what's behind Blue Dress Cup

    We feel that competition is a big part of being an artist. Artists in Milwaukee apply every year to the Nohl Fellowhsip Award, the Arts Board annually chooses an Artist of the Year, there is a constant stream of grants, residency applications, RFP’s that pit cultural producers against one another ceaselessly. Blue Dress Cup is an opportunity to take a break from all the serious competition, and enjoy venting our frustrations on the field. It’s a place for everyone who didn’t receive a grant, a solo show, get into a residency program, or a good grad school to enjoy the weather, eat a brat, and root for their favorite artist.



    (The night sky over Blue Dress Park, as rendered by John Riepenhoff)


    Other Ways to Get Involved

    Soon, we'll be looking for artists and creatives of all kinds to compete in this year's competition. If you think you or anyone you know has what it takes to be this year's Best Artist in Milwaukee, be sure to stay tuned!

story:
My name is Lindsey Barlag Thornton. 

I am a artist who recently graduated with my Masters from The School of the Art Institute of Chicago.

I am a hybrid performance artist/director/teaching artist. 

I don't fit into boxes easily. Sometimes that's empowering. Sometimes that's lonely.

As a little girl, I was fascinated with the idea of being a saint or an archeologist.

I am sort of obsessed with themes about death, the body, theories of time and space, the traces left by a human being, memory, and what constitutes a life.

My thesis at the Art Institute was called We Are The Things of Ghosts.

Sometimes, it's hard to tell as a performer what--if anything--resonates with the audience.

And sometimes, if I'm lucky, a piece comes along, takes me by the scruff of the neck, and brings me and everyone involved to another level of awe and gratitude. 

We Are The Things of Ghosts is such a piece.

It has left audiences stunned in their seats, the hardest of my beloved hipsters in tears, and one woman, long after the audience had left, still in her seat, grieving.

Did I mention that it's funny?

We Are The Things of Ghosts was devised (created) with a group of artists out of thin air. I came into the rehearsal room with a question and we started playing and what came out of the playing was shaped into moments and then text and then images and song and movement and all of that was furthermore shaped and scored into this piece: We Are The Things of Ghosts; a theatrical meditation on life, death, the body, and the traces we leave through our lives.

And did I mention that it's funny?

We return to We Are The Things of Ghosts, re-imagining it and further shaping the performance for its November production at Chicago's historical Copernicus Center. When it opened in 1930, it was called The Gateway Theatre, and the Chicago Herald Examiner called it "the most acoustically perfect theatre in the world." It was the first theatre built exclusively for "talkies", and, with its sky blue ceiling revealing night-time stars, it remains the only living atmospheric-style theatre in Chicago. It is the perfect location in which to perform We Are The Things of Ghosts, which serves as a theatrical gateway, taking you on a journey through sound and silence and image from the grave to the starry heavens of outer-space.

But did I mention that it's funny?

For three days only, We Are The Things of Ghosts comes to The Copernicus Center, and I hope you will, too. Right now--as that crisp chill rides along the wind and the leaves start to fall--seems the perfect time to immerse ourselves in this theatrical meditation about life and death. To laugh together. To grieve together. To embrace ever-constant Change.

Being a solo artist, I rely on individuals to fund works like this and future work I am falling in love with. I am not a non-for-profit with a board of directors. I am not supported by city and state grants. It's just me; still the weird curious girl staring off into space dreaming about the big things and sometimes fortunate enough to get to investigate those questions with a group of artists to create something for all of us to experience together, now.

We Are The Things of Ghosts.

Thank you for being here. 
What We Need
  • The budget for We Are The Things of Ghosts is $2,500. This covers space rental, props and costumes, compensation for the artists, and marketing. Since my work is often collaborative, I feel strongly about compensating the people with whom I make work for their time, talent, and commitment.

The Impact

I believe emotionally-available and impactful art can change the world.  I'm an unapologetic idealist and believe this tiny piece partly concerned with death can largely affirm how great it is to be alive.

    Risks & Challenges

    The hardest part--creating We Are The Things of Ghosts from scratch and refining it--is nearly over. Now comes the fundraising, always a tricky but necessary part of the artistic life. As this campaign is being launched a month out, expenses have already been paid out-of-pocket. I've chosen to be absolutist--all or nothing--with this campaign and I hope that conveys to you how serious I am about We Are The Things of Ghosts and how much I believe in it. This is what it costs, exactly, financially. 

    What it costs in other immeasurable ways (physical, emotional, mental) is oddly its own reward.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Buy your tickets today at:  wearethethingsofghosts.brownpapertickets.com

      Share this campaign at:

      #WeAreTheThingsOfGhosts

story:
Who are we?

For the past four years, we, the Black Rock Disc Golf Club, have been dedicated to setting up on the 2:00 avenue our custom 9-hole disc golf course for players of all skill levels to enjoy.  We bring a mix of donated discs and our own custom-stamped BRDGC discs for everyone to use.  Last year we doubled our efforts and brought a light-up mushroom forest as scenery and obstacles for the course, to much acclaim.
We host two tournaments during the week (one during the day, one at night with LED-ed discs) and are expanding to offer technical clinics and putting challenges as well.
You can check us out on Facebook (linked below) to see pictures of our past courses and events.
 

The Next Evolution

Every year we add something new to the course, growing it as best we can.  This year, we want to bring much more to the course, and to realize all our plans and dreams, we could use your help.
 
To get a little specific, here's what we have in mind:
We would like to increase the number of mushrooms in the forest, for which we need rebar, PVC piping, cloth, wire, and paint.
We would like to upgrade our lighting scheme from cheap solar garden lights to a deep-cycle-battery-powered LED system for our large obstacle mushrooms.
Transporting all this from the Bay Area costs us quite a bit, too.  Our trusty van, Preggers, has made the trip out the past two years, and we need to keep her well in shape to safely bring us out again this year.
 

Bringing The Awesome

A donation to our project will help us tremendously!  Be it $5, $50, or $500, every penny we receive will go in to making our course even better than previous years.  It is a wonderful feeling to bring our passion to the Playa and meet people who love the sport as much as we do and are surprised and stoked to see our project there.

Everything we can do to make everyone's experience better, we want to do.  Please donate today and come visit us this year at 2:00 and G!
